{{Infobox power station | name = Clyde Wind Farm | name_official = | image = Windfarm_at_Beattock,_taken_from_the_M74.jpg | image_alt = | image_caption = | location_map = UK Scotland |relief =1 | location_map_size = | location_map_caption= | location_map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|55|28|02|N|3|39|16|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | country = United Kingdom, Scotland | location = near [[Abington, South Lanarkshire]] | status = O | construction_began = | commissioned = 2012 | decommissioned = | cost = | owner = [[Scottish and Southern Energy]] | operator = | wind_farm_type = Onshore | wind_site_elevation = | wind_site_usage = | wind_site_area = | wind_offshore_depth = | wind_offshore_distance= | wind_hub_height = | wind_rotor_diameter = | wind_rated_speed = | ps_units_operational= 152 | ps_units_manu_model = | ps_units_uc = | ps_units_planned = | ps_units_decommissioned= | ps_electrical_capacity= 350 MW | ps_electrical_cap_fac= | ps_annual_generation= | th_cogeneration = | th_combined_cycle = | website = }} The '''Clyde Wind Farm''' is a 350 [[megawatt]] (MW) [[wind farm]] near [[Abington, South Lanarkshire|Abington]] in [[South Lanarkshire]], [[Scotland]].
==Planning== The 152-turbine project by [[Scottish and Southern Energy]] was approved by the [[Scottish Parliament]] in July 2008, and is capable of powering 200,000 homes.<ref>[http://www.sse.com/Clyde SSE Clyde Project website]</ref> SSE was given planning permission to build a wind farm with turbines built on either side of the [[M74 motorway]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/main.jhtml?xml=/earth/2008/07/21/eawind121.xml | title=Europe's largest onshore wind farm is to be built in Scotland costing £600m | first=Simon | last=Johnson | work=[[Telegraph.co.uk]] | publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] | date=2008-07-21 | accessdate=2008-07-22 }}</ref>
==Construction== Construction of the wind farm, which was budgeted for £600 million, began in early 2009 and finished in 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/7517176.stm | title=Green light for massive wind farm | publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=2008-07-21 | accessdate=2008-07-22 }}</ref> Welcon Towers Ltd won the contract to supply the towers for all 152 turbines for the £600 million Clyde Wind Farm. Jesper Øhlenschlæger, chief executive officer of Welcon Towers parent company Skykon, said: ‘The Clyde project is a very important business win for our Campbeltown manufacturing. Scotland has become the most positive and the most interesting renewable wind power market in Europe. The Clyde Wind Farm project represents a landmark phase in Scotland’s renewable energy strategy.’<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.campbeltowncourier.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/5284/Well_done_Welcon.html | title=Well Done Welcon | publisher=[[The Campbeltown Courier]] | date=2009-11-27 | accessdate=2009-12-01 }}</ref>
The farm was opened at a ceremonial ribbon cutting by [[First Minister of Scotland]] [[Alex Salmond]] in September 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sharecast.com/cgi-bin/sharecast/story.cgi?story_id=20363821 | title=Salmond opens SSE's Clyde wind farm}}</ref>
==Extension== In July 2014 it was announced that Scottish ministers had approved an extension to the Clyde Wind Farm.<ref name="bbc14">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-28446762 | title=Ministers approve two wind farm projects in Scotland | publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=2014-07-23 | accessdate=2014-07-23 }}</ref> The extension will see 54 extra turbines, capable of generating an additional 162MW. This will bring the total generating capacity of the wind farm to 512MW.<ref name="bbc14"/>
==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|Scotland|Weather|Renewable energy}}}} *[[Wind power in Scotland]] *[[List of onshore wind farms]]

'''Complex metal hydrides''' are salts wherein the anions contain [[hydride]]s. In the older chemical literature as well as contemporary [[Solid state chemistry|materials science]] textbooks, a "[[metal hydride]]" is assumed to be nonmolecular, i.e. three-dimensional lattices of atomic ions. In such systems, hydrides are often interstitial and [[nonstoichiometric compound|nonstoichiometric]], and the bonding between the metal and hydrogen atoms is significantly [[ionic bonding|ionic]]. In contrast, complex metal hydrides typically contain more than one type of metal or metalloid and may be soluble but invariably react with water. They exhibit ionic bonding between a positive metal ion with molecular [[anion]]s containing the hydride. In such materials the hydrogen is bonded with significant [[covalent]] character to the second metal or metalloid atoms.<ref name=Holle>Holleman, A. F.; Wiberg, E. "Inorganic Chemistry" Academic Press: San Diego, 2001. {{ISBN|0-12-352651-5}}.</ref>
==Examples== In general, complex metal hydrides have the formula M<sub>x</sub>M'<sub>y</sub>H<sub>n</sub>, where M is an alkali metal cation or cation complex and M' is a metal or metalloid. Well known examples feature [[group 13 element]]s, especially boron and aluminium including [[sodium aluminium hydride]], NaAlH<sub>4</sub> (also known as sodium alanate), [[lithium aluminum hydride]], LiAlH<sub>4</sub>, and [[lithium borohydride]], (LiBH<sub>4</sub>). Complex metal hydrides are often soluble in [[ether]]ial [[solvent]]s. Other complex metal hydrides are numerous. Illustrative examples include the salts [MgBr([[THF]])<sub>2</sub>]<sub>4</sub>FeH<sub>6</sub> and [[Potassium nonahydridorhenate|K<sub>2</sub>ReH<sub>9</sub>]].<ref name=Holle/>

{{Distinguish|Y-Δ transform}} [[File:Diapositiva14.PNG|thumb|283px|schematic]]
A '''delta-wye transformer''' is a type of [[three-phase]] [[electric power]] [[transformer]] design that employs delta-connected windings on its primary and wye/star connected windings on its secondary. A [[neutral wire]] can be provided on wye output side. It can be a single three-phase transformer, or built from three independent single-phase units. An equivalent term is '''delta-star transformer'''.
[[Image:DeltaWyeTransformer.svg|thumb|One possible ''delta-wye transformer'' configuration.<ref name="International Standard IEC 60076-1 Edition 2:1993 consolidated with amendment 1:1999">{{cite web|title=Annex D - Three-phase transformer connections|url=http://212.175.131.171/IEC/iec60076-1%7Bed2.1%7Den_d.pdf#page=43|publisher=IEC|accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref>]]
Delta-wye transformers are common in commercial, industrial, and high-density residential locations, to supply three-phase [[Electric power distribution|distribution systems]].
An example would be a distribution transformer with a delta primary, running on three 11 kV phases with no neutral or earth required, and a star (or wye) secondary providing a 3-phase supply at 415 V, with the domestic voltage of 240 available between each phase and the earthed (grounded) neutral point.
The delta winding allows third-harmonic currents to circulate within the transformer, and prevents third-harmonic currents from flowing in the supply line. <ref name=TANDD> ''Electrical Transmission and Distribution Reference Book,Westinghouse Electric Corporation'', 1964, Chapter 5, table 15</ref> Delta connected windings are not common for higher transmission voltages (138 kV and above) owing to the higher cost of insulation compared with a wye connection. <ref> Fink and Beaty, ''Standard Handbook for Electrical Engineers 11th Edition'', Mc Graw Hill 1978, page 17-39 </ref>
Delta-wye transformers introduce a 30, 150, 270 or 330 degree phase shift.<ref name="Annex D - Three-phase transformer connections">{{cite web|title=IEC Standard 60076-1 Edition 2:1993 consolidated with amendment 1:1999|url=http://212.175.131.171/IEC/iec60076-1%7Bed2.1%7Den_d.pdf#page=43|publisher=IEC|accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref> Thus they cannot be paralleled with wye-wye (or delta-delta) transformers. However, they can be paralleled with identical configurations and some different configurations of other delta-wye (or wye-delta with some attention) transformers.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}
==See also== * [[Electric power distribution]] * [[High-leg delta]] * [[Mains power systems]] * [[Motor soft starter]]

A '''deposit-refund system''' (DRS), also known as '''deposit-return system''', '''advance deposit fee''' or '''deposit-return scheme''', is a surcharge on a product when purchased and a rebate when it is returned. A well-known example is when [[container deposit legislation]] mandates that a refund is given when [[reusable packaging]] is returned. Deposit-refund system are a [[Market-based environmental policy instruments|market-based instrument]] to address [[Externality|externalities]]. As with [[Pigovian tax]]es a DRS aims to limit pollution of various types by creating an incentive to return a product.<ref name = Walls>{{cite web|url=http://www.rff.org/RFF/Documents/RFF-DP-11-47.pdf|title=Deposit-Refund Systems in Practice and Theory |last=Walls |first=Margaret |date=November 2011 |work=RFF DP 11-47 |publisher=Resources for the Future |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref>
While most commonly used with beverage containers it can be used on other materials including liquid and gaseous wastes.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Fullerton |first=Don |first2=Ann |last2=Wolverton |title=Two Generalizations of a Deposit-Refund System |journal=[[American Economic Review]] |year=2000 |volume=90 |issue=2 |pages=238–242 |doi=10.1257/aer.90.2.238 }}</ref> Deposit-refund systems are used on products such as batteries, tyres, [[Automotive oil recycling|automotive oil]], [[consumer electronics]] and shipping [[pallet]]s.
There are three potential advantages of a DRS: it reduces illegal dumping by giving a financial incentive, it makes monitoring and enforcement easier, and evading the costs is difficult.<ref name = Walls/>
Deposit-refund systems can be both voluntary or mandated by legislation.
==See also== *[[Environmental economics]] *[[Product stewardship]] *[[Circular economy]]

'''Dielectric absorption''' is the name given to the effect by which a [[capacitor]], that has been charged for a long time, discharges only incompletely when briefly discharged. Although an ideal capacitor would remain at zero [[volt]]s after being discharged, real capacitors will develop a small voltage from time-delayed dipole discharging, a phenomenon that is also called [[dielectric relaxation]], "soakage", or "battery action". For some [[dielectric]]s, such as many [[polymer]] films, the resulting voltage may be less than 1–2% of the original voltage, but it can be as much as 15% for [[electrolytic capacitor]]s. The voltage at the terminals generated by the dielectric absorption may possibly cause problems in the function of an electronic circuit or can be a safety risk to personnel. In order to prevent shocks, most very large capacitors are shipped with shorting wires that need to be removed before they are used.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.designers-guide.org/Modeling/da.pdf | title=Modeling Dielectric Absorption in Capacitors, by Ken Kundert}}</ref>
==Theory== [[Image:Diel.png|thumb| The random orientations of molecular dipoles in a dielectric are aligned under the influence of an electric field by applying a voltage to the electrodes.]] [[Image:Dielektrische Absorption.png|thumb|right| Circuit model for explaining a time-delayed voltage build-up by parallel RC-timers]]
Charging a capacitor (due to a voltage between the capacitor plates) causes an [[electric field]] to be applied to the [[dielectric]] between the electrodes. This field exerts a [[torque]] on the molecular [[dipole]]s, causing the directions of the dipole moments to align with the field direction. This change in the molecular dipoles is called [[Dielectric#Dipolar polarization|oriented polarization]] and also causes heat to be generated, resulting in [[dielectric losses]] (see [[dissipation factor]]). The orientation of the dipoles does not follow the electric field synchronously, but is delayed by a [[time constant]] that depends on the material. This delay corresponds to a [[hysteresis]] response of the polarization to the external field.
When the capacitor is discharging, the strength of the electric field is decreasing and the common orientation of the molecular dipoles is returning to an undirected state in a process of [[Relaxation (physics)|relaxation]]. Due to the hysteresis, at the zero point of the electric field, a material-dependent number of molecular dipoles are still polarized along the field direction without a measurable voltage appearing at the terminals of the capacitor. This is like an electrical [[remanence]]. The oriented dipoles will be discharged spontaneously over time and the voltage at the electrodes of the capacitor will [[exponential decay|decay exponentially]].<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://sound.whsites.net/articles/capacitors.htm#2.1 | title=Elliot sound products, 2.1 - Dielectric Absorption}}</ref> The complete discharge time of all dipoles can be days to weeks depending on the material. This "reloaded" voltage can be retained for months, even in [[electrolytic capacitor]]s, caused by the high insulation resistance in common modern capacitor dielectrics. The discharge of a capacitor and the subsequent reloading can be repeated several times.
==Measurement== Dielectric absorption is a property which has been long known. Its value can be measured in accordance with the IEC/EN 60384-1 standard. The capacitor shall be charged at the DC voltage rating for 60 minutes. Then the capacitor shall be disconnected from the power source and shall be discharged for 10 s. The voltage regained on the capacitor terminals (recovery voltage) within 15 minutes is the dielectric absorption voltage. The size of the dielectric absorption voltage is specified in relation to the applied voltage in percent and depends on the dielectric material used. It is specified by many manufacturers in the data sheets.<ref>WIMA, Characteristics of Metallized [[film capacitor]]s in Comparison with Other Dielectrics {{cite web |url=http://www.wima.de/EN/characteristics.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105021659/http://www.wima.de/EN/characteristics.htm |archivedate=2012-11-05 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.epcos.com/web/generator/Web/Sections/ProductCatalog/Capacitors/FilmCapacitors/PDF/PDF__GeneralTechnicalInformation,property=Data__en.pdf;/PDF_GeneralTechnicalInformation.pdf# |title=Film Capacitors, TDK Epcos, General technical information |access-date=2012-01-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201110951/http://www.epcos.com/web/generator/Web/Sections/ProductCatalog/Capacitors/FilmCapacitors/PDF/PDF__GeneralTechnicalInformation,property=Data__en.pdf;/PDF_GeneralTechnicalInformation.pdf# |archive-date=2012-02-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.avx.com/docs/techinfo/General/dielectr.pdf AVX, Dielectric Comparison Chart]</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.holystonecaps.com/PDF/TechNotes/200712181125470.Capdielectriccomp3.pdf# |title=Holystone, Capacitor Dielectric Comparison, Technical Note 3 |access-date=2012-01-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201110951/http://www.holystonecaps.com/PDF/TechNotes/200712181125470.Capdielectriccomp3.pdf# |archive-date=2012-02-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable centered" |- style="background-color:#ABCDEF" ! Type of capacitor ! Dielectric absorption |- | Air and vacuum capacitors || Not measurable |- | Class-1 [[ceramic capacitor]]s, NP0 || 0.6% |- | Class-2 ceramic capacitors, X7R || 2.5% |- | Polypropylene [[film capacitor]]s (PP) || 0.05 to 0.1% |- | Polyester film capacitors (PET) || 0.2 to 0.5% |- | Polyphenylene sulfide film capacitors (PPS) || 0.05 to 0.1% |- | Polyethylene naphthalate film capacitors (PEN) || 1.0 to 1.2% |- |[[Tantalum capacitor|Tantalum electrolytic capacitors]] with solid electrolyte || 2 to 3 %,<ref>[http://d0server1.fnal.gov/users/bagby/www/L1_Cal/ORC_Docs/Final_Orc/ADF_CAPS/KEMET_F3102PolTaPerChar.pdf Kemet, Polymer Tantalum Chip Capacitors]</ref> 10 %<ref name=AVX-DA>R. W. Franklin, AVX, ANALYSIS OF SOLID TANTALUM CAPACITOR LEAKAGE CURRENT ,[http://www.avx.com/docs/techinfo/1_Analysis.pdf PDF], [http://www.avx.com/docs/techinfo/Tantalum-NiobiumCapacitors/soltant.pdf PDF]</ref> |- | [[Electrolytic capacitor|Aluminium electrolytic capacitors]] with non-solid electrolyte || 10 to 15%<ref name=CDE>CDE, Aluminum Electrolytic Capacitor Application Guide, [http://www.cde.com/resources/catalogs/AEappGUIDE.pdf PDF]</ref> |- | [[Double-layer capacitor]] || data not available |}
==Design considerations and safety== The voltage at the terminals generated by the dielectric absorption may possibly cause problems in the function of an electronic circuit. For sensitive analog circuits such as [[sample and hold]] circuits, [[Operational amplifier applications#Integration and differentiation|integrators]], [[charge amplifier]]s or high-quality audio circuits, Class-1 ceramic or polypropylene capacitors instead of Class-2 ceramic capacitors, polyester film capacitors or electrolytic capacitors are used.<ref>National Semiconductors, Understand Capacitor Soakage to Optimize Analog Systems [http://www.national.com/rap/Application/0,1570,28,00.html] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123210736/http://www.national.com/rap/Application/0,1570,28,00.html# |date=2010-01-23 }}</ref> For most electronic circuits, particularly filtering applications, the small dielectric absorption voltage has no influence on the proper electrical function of the circuit. For aluminum electrolytic capacitors with non-solid electrolyte which are not built into a circuit, the dielectric absorption voltage generated can be a personnel safety risk.<ref>[http://www.keith-snook.info/capacitor-soakage.html]</ref> The voltage can be quite substantial, for example 50 V for 400 V electrolytic capacitors, and can cause damages to [[semiconductor device]]s, or cause sparks during installation in the circuit. Larger aluminum electrolytic capacitors and high-voltage power capacitors are transported and delivered short-circuited to dissipate this unwanted and possibly dangerous energy.
Another effect of dielectric absorption is sometimes described as "soakage". This manifests as a component of leakage current and it contributes to the loss factor of the capacitor. This effect has been known of only recently:{{Failed verification|date=January 2012}} it is now a proportionately greater part of leakage current due to the significantly improved properties of modern capacitors.<ref name=AVX-DA />
For double-layer capacitors, there are no figures from manufacturers available.
== See also == * [[Permittivity]] * [[Types of capacitor#Dielectric absorption (soakage)]] * [[Dielectric spectroscopy]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

'''Dwarf coconut''' is a range of varieties of [[coconut palm]]. The use of the word “dwarf” here does not refer to the tree’s size, as it can reach heights of 50-80 feet which is certainly not a dwarf. Instead, the dwarf designation refers to the size in which it will begin to produce the coveted or harvestable coconut.<ref>{{cite web|title=DWARF COCONUT PALM TREES|url=http://www.palmco.com/dwarf-coconut-palm-trees-for-sale.html|website=Palmco|accessdate=15 October 2016}}</ref>
==Dwarf varieties== Other types of dwarfs are: (in alphabetical order) *Cameroon Red Dwarf *Chowghat Dwarf Green *Chowghat Dwarf Orange *Coconino *Eburnea *Equatorial Guinea Green Dwarf *Equatorial Guinea Yellow Dwarf *Fiji Dwarf: form a large bulb at the lower stem *Gangabondam *Ghana Yellow Dwarf *Gon Thembili *Haari Papua *Kelapa Gading *Kelapa Radja *Laccadive Dwarf *Lakshadweep Dwarf *Maldive Dwarf *Mangipod *Mu-see-Keo *N'uleka *Nok-koom *Pilipog *Pugai *Pumila *Rath Thembli *Regia
===Malayan Dwarf=== The ''Malayan Dwarf'' is a variety of dwarf coconut. The palm is classified based on the nut color: ivory yellow nuts, apricot red nuts, and green nuts.<ref name=pk/> The palm's resistance to the [[Lethal Yellowing]] disease is the characteristic that makes it to be one of the important dwarf types in the world.<ref name=pk>P.K. Thampan. 1981. Handbook on Coconut Palm. Oxford & IBH Publishing Co.</ref>
Recognition of the Malayan Dwarf's resistance to lethal yellowing was in 1956 at [[Round Hill, Jamaica]], where the Malayan Dwarfs affected by the disease was only a very small percentage.<ref name=pk/>
==Hybrid varieties== The [[Maypan coconut palm]] is a ''Dwarf''x''Tall'' hybrid between the Malayan Dwarf and ''[[Panama Tall]]''.<ref name=pk/> The ''Dwarf''x''Tall'' hybrid between the Malayan Dwarf (yellow) and ''West African Tall'' is locally known as ''Mawa'', in Ivory Coast, Mawa is known as ''[[Port-Bouet-121]]''.<ref name=pk/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *P.K. Thampan, V.T. Markose. 1973. ''The Dwarf Coconut''. Directorate of Coconut Development, Cochin.

{{distinguish|Fermi level}} The '''Fermi energy''' is a concept in [[quantum mechanics]] usually referring to the energy difference between the highest and lowest occupied single-particle states in a quantum system of non-interacting [[fermion]]s at [[absolute zero]] [[temperature]]. In a [[Fermi gas]], the lowest occupied state is taken to have zero kinetic energy, whereas in a metal, the lowest occupied state is typically taken to mean the bottom of the [[conduction band]]. Confusingly, the term "Fermi energy" is often being used for referring to a different yet closely related concept, the [[Fermi level|Fermi ''level'']] (also called [[electrochemical potential]]).The use of the term "Fermi energy" as synonymous with [[Fermi level]] (a.k.a. [[electrochemical potential]]) is widespread in semiconductor physics. For example: [https://books.google.com/books?id=n0rf9_2ckeYC&pg=PA49 ''Electronics (fundamentals And Applications)''] by D. Chattopadhyay, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lmg13dHPKg8C&pg=PA113 ''Semiconductor Physics and Applications''] by Balkanski and Wallis. There are a few key differences between the Fermi level and Fermi energy, at least as they are used in this article: * The Fermi energy is only defined at absolute zero, while the Fermi level is defined for any temperature. * The Fermi energy is an energy ''difference'' (usually corresponding to a [[kinetic energy]]), whereas the Fermi level is a total energy level including kinetic energy and potential energy. * The Fermi energy can only be defined for [[Fermi gas|non-interacting fermions]] (where the potential energy or band edge is a static, well defined quantity), whereas the Fermi level (the electrochemical potential of an electron) remains well defined even in complex interacting systems, at thermodynamic equilibrium. Since the Fermi level in a metal at absolute zero is the energy of the highest occupied single particle state, then the Fermi energy in a metal is the energy difference between the Fermi level and lowest occupied single-particle state, at zero-temperature. ==Context== {{main|Fermi gas}} In [[quantum mechanics]], a group of particles known as [[fermion]]s (for example, [[electron]]s, [[proton]]s and [[neutron]]s) obey the [[Pauli exclusion principle]]. This states that two fermions cannot occupy the same [[quantum state]]. Since an idealized non-interacting Fermi gas can be analyzed in terms of single-particle [[stationary state]]s, we can thus say that two fermions cannot occupy the same stationary state. These stationary states will typically be distinct in energy. To find the ground state of the whole system, we start with an empty system, and add particles one at a time, consecutively filling up the unoccupied stationary states with the lowest energy. When all the particles have been put in, the '''Fermi energy''' is the kinetic energy of the highest occupied state. As a consequence, even if we have extracted all possible energy from a Fermi gas by cooling it to near [[absolute zero]] temperature, the fermions are still moving around at a high speed. The fastest ones are moving at a velocity corresponding to a kinetic energy equal to the Fermi energy. This speed is known as the '''Fermi velocity'''. Only when the temperature exceeds the related '''Fermi temperature''', do the electrons begin to move significantly faster than at absolute zero. The Fermi energy is an important concept in the [[solid state physics]] of metals and [[superconductor]]s. It is also a very important quantity in the physics of [[Superfluid|quantum liquid]]s like low temperature [[helium]] (both normal and superfluid 3He), and it is quite important to [[nuclear physics]] and to understanding the stability of [[White dwarf|white dwarf stars]] against [[gravitational collapse]]. ==Formula and typical values== The Fermi energy for fermions [[spin-½]] in a three-dimensional (non-[[Special relativity|relativistic]]) system is given by: :E_{\mathrm{F}} = \frac{\hbar^2}{2m_0} \left( \frac{3 \pi^2 N}{V} \right)^{2/3} , where ''N'' is the number of particles, ''m''0 the [[rest mass]] of each fermion, ''V'' the volume of the system and \hbar the reduced [[Planck constant]]. ===Metals=== Under the [[free electron model]], the electrons in a metal can be considered to form a Fermi gas. The number density N/V of conduction electrons in metals ranges between approximately 1028 and 1029 electrons/m3, which is also the typical density of atoms in ordinary solid matter. This number density produces a Fermi energy of the order of 2 to 10 [[electronvolts]].{{Cite web|url=http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/Tables/fermi.html|title=Fermi Energies, Fermi Temperatures, and Fermi Velocities|last=Nave|first=Rod|date=|website=[[HyperPhysics]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-21}} ===White dwarfs=== Stars known as [[white dwarfs]] have mass comparable to our [[Sun]], but have about a hundredth of its radius. The high densities mean that the electrons are no longer bound to single nuclei and instead form a degenerate electron gas. Their Fermi energy is about 0.3 MeV. ===Nucleus=== Another typical example is that of the [[nucleon]]s in the nucleus of an atom. The [[Nuclear size|radius of the nucleus]] admits deviations, so a typical value for the Fermi energy is usually given as 38 [[MeV]]. == Related quantities == Using this definition of above for the Fermi energy, various related quantities can be useful. The '''Fermi temperature''' is defined as: : T_{\mathrm{F}} = \frac{E_{\mathrm{F}}}{k_{\rm B}} where k_{\rm B} is the [[Boltzmann constant]] and E_{\mathrm{F}} the Fermi energy. The Fermi temperature can be thought of as the temperature at which thermal effects are comparable to quantum effects associated with Fermi statistics.{{Cite web|url=http://www.physics.usu.edu/torre/3700_Spring_2015/Lectures/08.pdf|title=PHYS 3700: Introduction to Quantum Statistical Thermodyamics|last=Torre|first=Charles|date=2015-04-21|website=Utah State University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-21}} The Fermi temperature for a metal is a couple of orders of magnitude above room temperature. Other quantities defined in this context are '''Fermi momentum''' : p_{\mathrm{F}} = \sqrt{2 m E_{\mathrm{F}}} , and '''Fermi velocity''' : v_{\mathrm{F}} = \frac{p_{\mathrm{F}}}{m}. These quantities are the [[momentum]] and [[group velocity]], respectively, of a [[fermion]] at the [[Fermi surface]]. The Fermi momentum can also be described as
p_{\mathrm{F}} = \hbar k_{\mathrm{F}} ,
where k_{\mathrm{F}} is the radius of the Fermi sphere and is called the '''Fermi wavevector'''.{{cite book|title=Solid State Physics|last=Ashcroft|first=Neil W.|last2=Mermin|first2=N. David|publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston|year=1976|isbn=978-0-03-083993-1|location=|pages=}} These quantities are ''not'' well-defined in cases where the [[Fermi surface]] is non-spherical. ==See also== * [[Fermi–Dirac statistics]]: the distribution of electrons over stationary states for non-interacting fermions at ''non-zero'' temperature. * [[Fermi Level]] * [[Quasi Fermi level]] == Notes == ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == *{{cite book |author1=Kroemer, Herbert |author2=Kittel, Charles | title=Thermal Physics (2nd ed.) | publisher=W. H. Freeman Company | year=1980 | isbn=978-0-7167-1088-2}} [[Category:Condensed matter physics]] [[Category:Fermi–Dirac statistics]]

{{Technical|date=February 2017}} The '''Foldy–Wouthuysen transform''' is widely used in [[high energy physics]]. It was historically formulated by [[Leslie Lawrance Foldy]] and [[Siegfried Adolf Wouthuysen]] in 1949 to understand the nonrelativistic limit of the [[Dirac equation]], the equation for [[spin-1/2|spin-{{sfrac|1|2}}]] particles.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Foldy|first1=L. L.|last2=Wouthuysen|first2=S. A.|date=1950|url=http://www.physics.drexel.edu/~bob/Quantum_Papers/Foldy-Wouthuysen.pdf|title=On the Dirac Theory of Spin {{1/2}} Particles and its Non-Relativistic Limit|journal=Physical Review|volume=78|issue=1|pages=29–36|bibcode=1950PhRv...78...29F|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.78.29}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Foldy|first1=L. L.|date=1952|title=The Electromagnetic Properties of the Dirac Particles|journal=Physical Review|volume=87|issue=5|pages=688–693|bibcode=1952PhRv...87..688F|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.87.688}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pryce|first1=M. H. L.|date=1948|title=The mass-centre in the restricted theory of relativity and its connexion with the quantum theory of elementary particles|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London A|volume=195|issue=1040|pages=62–81|bibcode=1948RSPSA.195...62P|doi=10.1098/rspa.1948.0103}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tani|first1=S.|date=1951|title=Connection between particle models and field theories. I. The case spin {{1/2}}|journal=Progress of Theoretical Physics|volume=6|issue=3|pages=267–285|bibcode=1951PThPh...6..267T|doi=10.1143/ptp/6.3.267}}</ref> A detailed general discussion of the Foldy–Wouthuysen-type transformations in particle interpretation of relativistic wave equations is in Acharya and Sudarshan (1960).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Acharya|first1=R.|last2=Sudarshan|first2=E. C. G.|date=1960|title=Front Description in Relativistic Quantum Mechanics|journal=Journal of Mathematical Physics|volume=1|issue=6|pages=532–536|bibcode=1960JMP.....1..532A|doi=10.1063/1.1703689}}</ref>
==A canonical transform== The FW transformation is a unitary transformation of the [[orthonormal]] basis in which both the [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]] and the state are represented. The [[eigenvalue]]s do not change under such a unitary transformation, that is, the physics does not change under such a unitary basis transformation. Therefore, such a unitary transformation can always be applied: in particular a unitary basis transformation may be picked which will put the Hamiltonian in a more pleasant form, at the expense of a change in the state function, which then represents something else. See for example the [[Bogoliubov transformation]], which is an orthogonal basis transform for the same purpose. The suggestion that the FW transform is applicable to the state ''or'' the Hamiltonian is thus not correct.
Foldy and Wouthuysen made use of a [[canonical transformation|canonical transform]] that has now come to be known as the ''Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation''. A brief account of the history of the transformation is to be found in the obituaries of Foldy and Wouthuysen<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brown|first1=R. W.|last2=Krauss|first2=L. M.|last3=Taylor|first3=P. L.|date=2001|title=Obituary of Leslie Lawrence Foldy|journal=Physics Today|volume=54|issue=12|page=75|doi=10.1063/1.1445566|bibcode=2001PhT....54l..75B}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leopold|first1=H.|date=1997|title=Obituary of Siegfried A Wouthuysen|journal=Physics Today|volume=50|issue=11|page=89|doi=10.1063/1.882018|bibcode=1997PhT....50k..89H}}</ref> and the biographical memoir of Foldy.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Foldy|first1=L. L.|date=2006|contribution=Origins of the FW Transformation: A Memoir|pages=347–351|title=Physics at a Research University: Case Western Reserve University 1830–1990|url=http://www.phys.cwru.edu/history|editor-first=William|editor-last=Fickinger}}</ref> Before their work, there was some difficulty in understanding and gathering all the interaction terms of a given order, such as those for a Dirac particle immersed in an external field. With their procedure the physical interpretation of the terms was clear, and it became possible to apply their work in a systematic way to a number of problems that had previously defied solution.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bjorken|first1=J. D.|last2=Drell|first2=S. D.|date=1964|title=Relativistic Quantum Mechanics|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=New York, San Francisco}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Costella|first1=J. P.|last2=McKellar|first2=B. H. J.|date=1995|title=The Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation|arxiv=hep-ph/9503416|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=63|issue=12|pages=1119–1124|doi=10.1119/1.18017|bibcode=1995AmJPh..63.1119C}}</ref> The Foldy–Wouthuysen transform was extended to the physically important cases of [[spin-0]] and [[spin-1]] particles,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Case|first1=K. M.|date=1954|title=Some generalizations of the Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation|journal=Physical Review|volume=95|issue=5|pages=1323–1328|bibcode=1954PhRv...95.1323C|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.95.1323}}</ref> and even generalized to the case of arbitrary [[Spin (physics)|spins]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jayaraman|first1=J.|date=1975|title=A note on the recent Foldy–Wouthuysen transformations for particles of arbitrary spin|journal=Journal of Physics A|volume=8|issue=1|page=L1–L4|bibcode=1975JPhA....8L...1J|doi=10.1088/0305-4470/8/1/001}}</ref>
==Description==
The Foldy–Wouthuysen (FW) transformation is a unitary transformation on a [[fermion]] [[wave function]] of the form:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\psi \to \psi '=U\psi </math>|{{EquationRef|1}}}}
where the unitary operator is the 4 × 4 matrix:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>U=e^{\beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \theta} = \mathbb{I}_4 \cos \theta + \beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \sin \theta =e^{\boldsymbol{\gamma} \cdot \hat{p} \theta} = \mathbb{I}_4 \cos \theta + \boldsymbol{\gamma} \cdot \hat{p} \sin \theta </math>|{{EquationRef|2}}}}
Above,
:<math>\hat{p}^i \equiv \frac{p^i}{|p|}</math>
is the unit vector oriented in the direction of the fermion momentum. The above are related to the [[Dirac matrices]] by {{math|''β'' {{=}} ''γ''<sup>0</sup>}} and {{math|''α<sup>i</sup>'' {{=}} ''γ''<sup>0</sup>''γ''<sup>''i''</sup>}}, with {{math|''i'' {{=}} 1, 2, 3}}. A straightforward series expansion applying the [[commutativity]] properties of the Dirac matrices demonstrates that {{EquationNote|2}} above is true. The inverse
:<math>U^{-1}=e^{-\beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \theta} = \cos \theta - \beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \sin \theta</math>
so it is clear that {{math|''U''<sup>−1</sup>''U'' {{=}} ''I''}}, where {{math|''I''}} is a 4 × 4 [[identity matrix]].
==Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation of the Dirac Hamiltonian for a free fermion==
This transformation is of particular interest when applied to the free-fermion Dirac Hamiltonian operator
:<math>\hat{H}_0 \equiv \alpha \cdot p + \beta m</math>
in biunitary fashion, in the form:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\begin{align}\hat{H}_0 \to \hat{H}'_0 &\equiv U \hat{H}_0 U^{-1} \\&= U (\alpha \cdot p + \beta m) U^{-1} \\&= (\cos \theta + \beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \sin \theta ) (\alpha \cdot p + \beta m) (\cos \theta - \beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \sin \theta ) \end{align}</math>|{{EquationRef|3}}}}
Using the commutativity properties of the Dirac matrices, this can be massaged over into the double-angle expression:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\begin{align}\hat{H}'_0 &= (\alpha \cdot p + \beta m) (\cos \theta - \beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \sin \theta )^2 \\&= (\alpha \cdot p + \beta m) e^{-2\beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \theta} \\&= (\alpha \cdot p + \beta m) (\cos 2\theta - \beta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \hat{p} \sin 2\theta ) \end{align}</math>|{{EquationRef|4}}}}
This factors out into:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{H}'_0= \alpha \cdot p \left(\cos 2\theta - \frac{m}{|p|} \sin 2\theta \right) + \beta (m \cos 2\theta + |p| \sin 2\theta)</math>|{{EquationRef|5}}}}
==Choosing a particular representation: Newton–Wigner==
Clearly, the FW transformation is a ''continuous'' transformation, that is, one may employ any value for {{mvar|θ}} which one chooses. Now comes the distinct question of choosing a particular value for {{mvar|θ}}, which amounts to choosing a particular transformed representation.
One particularly important representation, is that in which the transformed Hamiltonian operator {{math|''Ĥ''′<sub>0</sub>}} is diagonalized. Clearly, a completely diagonalized representation can be obtained by choosing {{mvar|θ}} such that the {{math|''α'' · ''p''}} term in {{EquationNote|5}} is made to vanish. Such a representation is specified by defining:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\tan 2\theta \equiv \frac{|p|}{m}</math>|{{EquationRef|6}}}}
so that {{EquationNote|5}} is reduced to the diagonalized (this presupposes that {{mvar|β}} is taken in the Dirac–Pauli representation (after [[Paul Dirac]] and [[Wolfgang Pauli]]) in which it is a diagonal matrix):
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{H}'_0= \beta (m \cos 2\theta + |p| \sin 2\theta)</math>|{{EquationRef|7}}}}
By elementary trigonometry, {{EquationNote|6}} also implies that:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\sin 2\theta = \frac{|p|}\sqrt{m^2+|p|^2} \quad \text{and} \quad \cos 2\theta = \frac{m}\sqrt{m^2+|p|^2} </math>|{{EquationRef|8}}}}
so that using {{EquationNote|8}} in {{EquationNote|7}} now leads following reduction to:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{H}'_0= \beta \sqrt{m^2+|p|^2}</math>|{{EquationRef|9}}}}
Prior to Foldy and Wouthuysen publishing their transformation, it was already known that {{EquationNote|9}} is the Hamiltonian in the Newton–Wigner (NW) representation (named after [[Theodore Duddell Newton]] and [[Eugene Wigner]]) of the [[Dirac equation]]. What {{EquationNote|9}} therefore tells us, is that by applying a FW transformation to the Dirac–Pauli representation of Dirac's equation, and then selecting the continuous transformation parameter {{mvar|θ}} so as to diagonalize the Hamiltonian, one arrives at the NW representation of Dirac's equation, because NW itself already contains the Hamiltonian specified in ({{EquationNote|9}}). See this [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.27.3209&rep=rep1&type=pdf link].
If one considers an on-shell mass—fermion or otherwise—given by {{math|''m''<sup>2</sup> {{=}} ''p<sup>σ</sup>p<sub>σ</sub>''}}, and employs a [[Minkowski metric]] tensor for which {{math|diag(''η'') {{=}} (+1, −1, −1, −1)}}, it should be apparent that the expression :<math> p^0 = \sqrt{m^2 + |p|^2} </math> is equivalent to the {{math|''E'' ≡ ''p''<sup>0</sup>}} component of the energy-momentum vector {{mvar|p<sup>μ</sup>}}, so that {{EquationNote|9}} is alternatively specified rather simply by {{math|''Ĥ''′<sub>0</sub> {{=}} ''βE''}}.
==Correspondence between the Dirac–Pauli and Newton–Wigner representations, for a fermion at rest==
Now let us consider a fermion at rest, which we may define in this context as a fermion for which {{math|{{abs|''p''}} {{=}} 0}}. From {{EquationNote|6}} or {{EquationNote|8}}, this means that {{math|cos 2''θ'' {{=}} 1}}, so that {{math|''θ'' {{=}} 0, ±π, ±2π}} and, from {{EquationNote|2}}, that the unitary operator {{math|''U'' {{=}} ±''I''}}. Therefore, any operator {{mvar|O}} in the Dirac-Pauli representation upon which we perform a biunitary transformation, will be given, for an at-rest fermion, by:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>O \to O' \equiv U O U^{-1} = (\pm I) (O) (\pm I) = O</math>|{{EquationRef|10}}}}
Contrasting the original Dirac–Pauli Hamiltonian operator
:<math>\hat{H}_0 \equiv \alpha \cdot p + \beta m</math>
with the NW Hamiltonian {{EquationNote|9}}, we do indeed find the {{math|{{abs|''p''}} {{=}} 0}} "at rest" correspondence:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{H}_0 = \hat{H}'_0= \beta m</math>|{{EquationRef|11}}}}
==The velocity operator in the Dirac–Pauli representation==
Now, let us consider the velocity operator. To obtain this operator, we must commute the Hamiltonian operator {{math|''Ĥ''′<sub>0</sub>}} with the canonical position operators {{mvar|x<sub>i</sub>}}, i.e., we must calculate
:<math>\hat{v_i}\equiv i\left[\hat{H}_0,x_i\right]</math>
One good way to approach this calculation, is to start by writing the scalar [[rest mass]] {{mvar|m}} as
:<math>m=\gamma^0\hat{H}_0+\gamma^jp_j</math>
and then to mandate that the scalar rest mass commute with the {{mvar|x<sub>i</sub>}}. Thus, we may write:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>0=[m,x_i]=\left[\left(\gamma^0\hat{H}_0+\gamma^jp_j\right),x_i\right]=\left[\gamma^0\hat{H}_0,x_i\right]+i\gamma_i</math>|{{EquationRef|12}}}}
where we have made use of the Heisenberg canonical commutation relationship {{math|[''x<sub>i</sub>'',''p<sub>j</sub>''] {{=}} −''iη<sub>ij</sub>''}} to reduce terms. Then, multiplying from the left by {{math|''γ''<sup>0</sup>}} and rearranging terms, we arrive at:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\frac{d\hat{x}_i}{dt}=\hat{v_i}\equiv i\left[\hat{H}_0,x_i\right]=\alpha_i</math>|{{EquationRef|13}}}}
Because the canonical relationship
:<math>i\left[\hat{H}_0,\hat{v}_i\right] \ne 0</math>
the above provides the basis for computing an inherent, non-zero acceleration operator, which specifies the oscillatory motion known as [[zitterbewegung]].
==The velocity operator in the Newton–Wigner representation==
In the Newton–Wigner representation, we now wish to calculate
:<math>\hat{v}_i'\equiv i\left[\hat{H}'_0,x_i\right]</math>
If we use the result at the very end of section 2 above, {{math|''Ĥ''′<sub>0</sub> {{=}} ''βp''<sub>0</sub>}}, then this can be written instead as:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{v}_i'\equiv i\left[\hat{H}'_0,x_i\right]=i \beta \left[p_0,x_i\right] </math>|{{EquationRef|14}}}}
Using the above, we need simply to calculate {{math|[''p''<sub>0</sub>,''x<sub>i</sub>'']}}, then multiply by {{mvar|iβ}}.
The canonical calculation proceeds similarly to the calculation in section 4 above, but because of the square root expression in {{math|''p''<sup>0</sup> {{=}} {{sqrt|''m''<sup>2</sup> + {{abs|''p''}}<sup>2</sup>}}}}, one additional step is required.
First, to accommodate the square root, we will wish to require that the scalar square mass {{math|''m''<sup>2</sup>}} commute with the canonical coordinates {{mvar|x<sub>i</sub>}}, which we write as:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>0 \equiv \left[m^2,x_i\right] = \left[\left(p^0p_0+p^jp_j\right),x_i\right] = \left[p^0p_0,x_i\right]+2ip_i</math>|{{EquationRef|15}}}}
where we again use the Heisenberg canonical relationship {{math|[''x<sub>i</sub>'',''p<sub>j</sub>''] {{=}} −''iη<sub>ij</sub>''}}. Then, we need an expression for {{math|[''p''<sub>0</sub>,''x<sub>i</sub>'']}} which will satisfy {{EquationNote|15}}. It is straightforward to verify that:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>i\left[p_0,x_i\right]=\frac{p_i}{p^0}=v_i</math>|{{EquationRef|16}}}}
will satisfy {{EquationNote|15}} when again employing {{math|[''x<sub>i</sub>'',''p<sub>j</sub>''] {{=}} −''iη<sub>ij</sub>''}}. Now, we simply return the {{mvar|iβ}} factor via {{EquationNote|14}}, to arrive at:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\frac{d\hat{x}_i'}{dt}=\hat{v}_i'\equiv i\left[\hat{H}'_0,x_i\right] = \beta \frac{p_i}{p^0} = \beta v_i </math>|{{EquationRef|17}}}}
This is understood to be the velocity operator in the Newton–Wigner representation. Because:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>i\left[\hat{H}'_0,\hat{v}_i'\right]=i\left[\beta p_0,\beta v_i\right]=0</math>|{{EquationRef|18}}}}
it is commonly thought that the [[zitterbewegung]] motion arising out of {{EquationNote|12}} vanishes when a fermion is transformed into the Newton–Wigner representation.
==The velocity operators for a fermion at rest==
Now, let us compare equations {{EquationNote|13}} and {{EquationNote|17}} for a fermion at rest, defined earlier in section 3 as a fermion for which {{math|{{abs|''p''}} {{=}} 0}}. Here, ({{EquationNote|13}}) remains:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{v}_i\equiv i\left[\hat{H}_0,x_i\right]=\alpha_i</math>|{{EquationRef|19}}}}
while {{EquationNote|17}} becomes:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{v}_i'\equiv i\left[\hat{H}'_0,x_i\right] = \beta \frac{p_i}{p^0} = 0 </math>|{{EquationRef|20}}}}
In equation {{EquationNote|10}} we found that for a fermion at rest, {{math|''O''′ {{=}} ''O''}} for any operator. One would expect this to include:
{{NumBlk|:|<math>\hat{v}_i'=\hat{v}_i</math>|{{EquationRef|21}}}}
however, equations {{EquationNote|19}} and {{EquationNote|20}} for a {{math|{{abs|''p''}} {{=}} 0}} fermion appear to contradict {{EquationNote|21}}.
==Other applications== {{ExcessiveCitations|section|date=February 2017}}
The powerful machinery of the Foldy–Wouthuysen transform originally developed for the [[Dirac equation]] has found applications in many situations such as [[acoustics]], and [[optics]].
It has found applications in very diverse areas such as atomic systems<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Asaga|first1=T.|last2=Fujita|first2=T.|last3=Hiramoto|first3=M.|date=2000|title=EDM operator free from Schiff's theorem|arxiv=hep-ph/0005314|journal=Progress in Theoretical Physics|volume=106|issue=6|pages=1223–1238|doi=10.1143/PTP.106.1223|bibcode=2001PThPh.106.1223A}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pachucki|first1=K.|date=2004|title=Higher-order effective Hamiltonian for light atomic systems|arxiv=physics/0411168|journal=Physical Review A|volume=71|issue=1|page=012503|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.71.012503|bibcode=2005PhRvA..71a2503P}}</ref> [[synchrotron]] radiation<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lippert|first1=M.|last2=Bruckel|first2=Th.|last3=Kohler|first3=Th.|last4=Schneider|first4=J. R.|date=1994|title=High-Resolution Bulk Magnetic Scattering of High-Energy Synchrotron Radiation|journal=Europhysics Letters|volume=27|issue=7|pages=537–541|bibcode=1994EL.....27..537L|doi=10.1209/0295-5075/27/7/008}}</ref> and derivation of the [[Bloch equation]] for [[spin polarization|polarized]] beams.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Heinemann|first1=K.|last2=Barber|first2=D. P.|date=1999|contribution=The semiclassical Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation and the derivation of the Bloch equation for spin-{{1/2}} polarized beams using Wigner functions|arxiv=physics/9901044|editor-last=Chen|editor-first=P|title=Proceedings of the 15th Advanced ICFA Beam Dynamics Workshop on Quantum Aspects of Beam Physics, 4–9 January 1998, Monterey, California, USA|pages=physics/9901044|publisher=World Scientific|location=Singapore|bibcode=1999physics...1044H}}</ref>
The application of the Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation in acoustics is very natural; comprehensive and mathematically rigorous accounts.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fishman|first1=L.|date=1992|title=Exact and operator rational approximate solutions of the Helmholtz, Weyl composition equation in underwater acoustics—the quadratic profile|journal=Journal of Mathematical Physics|volume=33|issue=5|pages=1887–1914|bibcode=1992JMP....33.1887F|doi=10.1063/1.529666}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Fishman|first1=L.|date=2004|contribution=One-way wave equation modeling in two-way wave propagation problems|editor1-first=B.|editor1-last=Nilsson|editor2-first=L.|editor2-last=Fishman|title=Mathematical Modelling of Wave Phenomena 2002, Mathematical Modelling in Physics, Engineering and Cognitive Sciences|volume=7|publisher=Växjö University Press|location=Växjö, Sweden|pages=91–111}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wurmser|first1=D.|date=2004|title=A parabolic equation for penetrable rough surfaces: using the Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation to buffer density jumps|journal=Annals of Physics|volume=311|issue=1|pages=53–80|bibcode=2004AnPhy.311...53W|doi=10.1016/j.aop.2003.11.006}}</ref>
In the traditional scheme the purpose of expanding the optical Hamiltonian
:<math> \hat{H} = - \left( n^2 (r) - \hat{p}_\perp^2 \right)^\frac12</math>
in a series using
:<math>\frac{\hat{p}_\perp^2}{n_0^2}</math>
as the expansion parameter is to understand the propagation of the quasi-paraxial beam in terms of a series of approximations (paraxial plus nonparaxial). Similar is the situation in the case of charged-particle optics. Let us recall that in relativistic quantum mechanics too one has a similar problem of understanding the relativistic wave equations as the nonrelativistic approximation plus the relativistic correction terms in the quasi-relativistic regime. For the Dirac equation (which is first-order in time) this is done most conveniently using the Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation leading to an iterative diagonalization technique. The main framework of the newly developed formalisms of optics (both light optics and charged-particle optics) is based on the transformation technique of Foldy–Wouthuysen theory which casts the Dirac equation in a form displaying the different interaction terms between the Dirac particle and an applied electromagnetic field in a nonrelativistic and easily interpretable form.
In the Foldy–Wouthuysen theory the Dirac equation is decoupled through a canonical transformation into two two-component equations: one reduces to the [[Pauli equation]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Osche|first=G. R.|date=1977|title=Dirac and Dirac–Pauli equation in the Foldy–Wouthuysen representation|journal=Physical Review D|volume=15|issue=8|pages=2181–2185|bibcode=1977PhRvD..15.2181O|doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.15.2181}}</ref> in the nonrelativistic limit and the other describes the negative-energy states. It is possible to write a Dirac-like [[Matrix Representation of Maxwell Equations|matrix representation of Maxwell's equations]]. In such a matrix form the Foldy–Wouthuysen can be applied.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Białynicki-Birula|first=I.|date=1996|arxiv=quant-ph/0508202|title=Photon wave function|journal=Progress in Optics|volume=36|issue=1996|pages=245–294|bibcode=2005quant.ph..8202B}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Sameen Ahmed|last=Khan|year=2005|arxiv=physics/0205083|title=Maxwell Optics: I. An exact matrix representation of the Maxwell equations in a medium|journal=Physica Scripta|volume=71|issue=5|pages=440–442|doi=10.1238/Physica.Regular.071a00440|bibcode=2005PhyS...71..440K}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1-link=Otto Laporte|last1=Laporte|first1=O.|author2-link=George Uhlenbeck|last2=Uhlenbeck|first2=G. E.|date=1931|title=Applications of spinor analysis to the Maxwell and Dirac Equations|journal=Physical Review|volume=37|issue=11|pages=1380–1397|bibcode=1931PhRv...37.1380L|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.37.1380}}</ref><ref>[[Ettore Majorana|Majorana, E.]] (1974). Unpublished notes, quoted in {{cite journal|last1=Mignani|first1=R.|last2=Recami|first2=E.|last3=Baldo|first3=M.|title=About a Dirac-like Equation for the Photon, According to Ettore Majorana|journal=Lettere al Nuovo Cimento|volume=11|issue=12|pages=568–572|doi=10.1007/bf02812391|year=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Moses|first=E.|date=1959|title=Solutions of Maxwell's equations in terms of a spinor notation: the direct and inverse problems|journal=Physical Review|volume=113|issue=6|pages=1670–1679|bibcode=1959PhRv..113.1670M|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.113.1670}}</ref>
There is a close algebraic analogy between the [[Helmholtz equation]] (governing scalar optics) and the [[Klein–Gordon equation]]; and between the [[Matrix representation of Maxwell's equations|matrix form of the Maxwell's equations]] (governing vector optics) and the [[Dirac equation]]. So it is natural to use the powerful machinery of standard quantum mechanics (particularly, the Foldy–Wouthuysen transform) in analyzing these systems.
The suggestion to employ the Foldy–Wouthuysen Transformation technique in the case of the Helmholtz equation was mentioned in the literature as a remark.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fishman|first1=L.|last2=McCoy|first2=J. J.|date=1984|title=Derivation and Application of Extended Parabolic Wave Theories. Part I. The Factored Helmholtz Equation|journal=Journal of Mathematical Physics|volume=25|issue=2|pages=285–296|bibcode=1984JMP....25..285F|doi=10.1063/1.526149}}</ref>
It was only in the recent works, that this idea was exploited to analyze the quasiparaxial approximations for specific beam optical system.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Sameen Ahmed|last1=Khan|first2=Ramaswamy|last2=Jagannathan|author3-link=Rajiah Simon|first3=Rajiah|last3=Simon|date=2002|title=Foldy–Wouthuysen transformation and a quasiparaxial approximation scheme for the scalar wave theory of light beams|pages=physics/0209082|arxiv=physics/0209082|bibcode=2002physics...9082K}}</ref> The Foldy–Wouthuysen technique is ideally suited for the [[Lie algebra]]ic approach to optics. With all these plus points, the powerful and ambiguity-free expansion, the Foldy–Wouthuysen Transformation is still little used in optics. The technique of the Foldy–Wouthuysen Transformation results in what is known as nontraditional prescriptions of Helmholtz optics<ref>{{cite journal|first=Sameen Ahmed|last1=Khan|year=2005|title=Wavelength-dependent modifications in Helmholtz Optics|journal=International Journal of Theoretical Physics|volume=44|issue=1|pages=95–125|doi=10.1007/s10773-005-1488-0|arxiv=physics/0210001|bibcode=2005IJTP...44...95K}}</ref> and Maxwell optics<ref>{{cite book|first=Sameen Ahmed|last1=Khan|date=2006|contribution=Wavelength-Dependent Effects in Light Optics|title=New Topics in Quantum Physics Research|editor1-first=Volodymyr|editor1-last=Krasnoholovets|editor2-first=Frank|editor2-last=Columbus|publisher=Nova Science Publishers|location=New York|pages=163–204}}</ref> respectively. The nontraditional approaches give rise to very interesting wavelength-dependent modifications of the paraxial and aberration behaviour. The nontraditional formalism of Maxwell optics provides a unified framework of light beam optics and polarization. The nontraditional prescriptions of light optics are closely analogous with the quantum theory of charged-particle beam optics.<ref>{{cite journal|first1=R.|last1=Jagannathan|first2=R.|last2=Simon|author3-link=George Sudarshan|first3=E. C. G.|last3=Sudarshan|author4-link=Narasimhaiengar Mukunda|first4=N.|last4=Mukunda|doi=10.1016/0375-9601(89)90685-3|title=Quantum theory of magnetic electron lenses based on the Dirac equation|journal=Physics Letters A|volume=134|issue=8–9|pages=457–464|date=1989|bibcode=1989PhLA..134..457J}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first1=R.|last1=Jagannathan|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.42.6674|title=Quantum theory of electron lenses based on the Dirac equation|journal=Physical Review A|volume=42|issue=11|pages=6674–6689|date=1990|bibcode=1990PhRvA..42.6674J}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|first=S. A.|last1=Khan|doi=10.1016/S1076-5670(08)70096-X|title=Quantum theory of the optics of charged particles|volume=97|pages=257–358|date=1996|series=Advances in Imaging and Electron Physics|isbn=9780120147397}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Conte|first1=M.|last2=Jagannathan|first2=R.|last3=Khan|first3=S. A.|last4=Pusterla|first4=M.|date=1996|title=Beam optics of the Dirac particle with anomalous magnetic moment|journal=Particle Accelerators|volume=56|pages=99–126}}</ref> In optics, it has enabled the deeper connections in the wavelength-dependent regime between light optics and charged-particle optics to be seen (see [[Electron optics]]).<ref>{{cite journal|first=Sameen Ahmed|last1=Khan|date=2006|doi=10.1016/j.ijleo.2005.11.010|title=The Foldy–Wouthuysen Transformation Technique in Optics|journal=Optik International Journal for Light and Electron Optics|volume=117|issue=10|pages=481–488|bibcode=2006Optik.117..481K}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|first=Sameen Ahmed|last1=Khan|doi=10.1016/S1076-5670(08)00602-2|title=The Foldy–Wouthuysen Transformation Technique in Optics|volume=152|pages=49–78|date=2008|series=Advances in Imaging and Electron Physics|isbn=9780123742193}}</ref>

{{Infobox power station | name = Gansu Dunhuang Solar Park | name_official = | image = File:Dunhuang.champs.de.panneaux.solaires.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = A part of the station | image_alt = | location_map = China | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|40|04|N|94|30|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = [[China]] | location = [[Gansu Province]] | status = O | construction_began = | commissioned = January 2013 | decommissioned = | cost = | owner = | operator = | solar_type = pv | solar_csp_heliostats = | solar_site_area = | ps_electrical_capacity = 50 [[Megawatt|MW]]<sup>p</sup> | ps_electrical_cap_fac = | ps_annual_generation = 78.2 [[GWh]]<ref>[http://cdm.unfccc.int/filestorage/k/4/0S6ZWQA1IO7J354XPEURKYLMD2VNBF.pdf/PDD.pdf?t=alV8bmk0Mzd5fDA9-01sUwDqomBW7jBBbn7o Project Design Document]</ref>{{rp|2,5}} | website = | extra = }} The '''Gansu Dunhuang Solar Park''' is a 50-[[megawatt]] (MW) [[photovoltaic power station]] located in the [[Gansu Province]], in China. All of the modules, which range from 230 to 240 [[watt]]s, are mounted at a fixed tilt angle of 38°. It is located in the ''Photoelectricity Park of Dunhuang City''.<ref>[http://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/DB/TECO1348832160.15/view Gansu Dunhuang 50MWp Solar PV Power Station Project]</ref> China's first solar power plant, 10 MW, was built here and commissioned on 30 September 2009. An additional 95 MW is expected in 2013, and 5,000 MW by 2020.<ref>[http://www.academics.com/science/the_solar_revolution_51886.html The solar revolution]</ref>

{{Infobox dam | name = Hatgyi Dam | name_official = | image = Salween watershed.png | image_size = | image_caption = Salween River watershed | image_alt = | location_map = Burma | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | location_map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|17|31|41|N|97|44|49|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = [[Myanmar]] | location = Hat Gyi, [[Karen State]] | purpose = Power | status = Proposed | construction_began = | opening = | demolished = | cost = | owner = | dam_type = | dam_crosses = [[Salween River]] | dam_length = | dam_height = {{Convert|33|m|ft|abbr=on}} | dam_height_foundation= | dam_height_thalweg = | dam_elevation_crest = | dam_width_crest = | dam_width_base = | dam_volume = | spillway_count = | spillway_type = | spillway_capacity = | res_name = | res_capacity_total = | res_capacity_active = | res_capacity_inactive= | res_catchment = | res_surface = | res_max_length = | res_max_width = | res_max_depth = | res_elevation = | res_tidal_range = | plant_name = | plant_coordinates = | plant_operator = | plant_commission = | plant_decommission = | plant_type = | plant_turbines = | plant_hydraulic_head = | plant_capacity = 1,365 MW (est.)<ref>{{cite web|title=Hatgyi Dam|url=http://burmariversnetwork.org/index.php/dam-projects/salween-dams/hatgyi|publisher=Burma Rivers Network|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref> | plant_annual_gen = | website = | extra = }} The '''Hatgyi Dam''' ({{lang-my|ဟတ်ကြီးဆည်}}) is a planned [[hydropower]] [[gravity dam]] to be constructed on the [[Salween River]] in southeastern [[Myanmar]]. The dam site is in Myanmar’s [[Karen State]]. The dam project is being funded by the [[Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand]] (EGAT), [[China]]'s [[Sinohydro Corporation]], and Myanmar's Ministry of Electric Power and International Group of Entrepreneurs (IGE). The dam is expected to produce 1,100 to 1,500 megawatts of power, the majority of which will be sent to [[Thailand]].<ref name="karen rebels">{{cite news|title=Democratic Voice of Burma: Karen rebels ordered to leave area near Thai-backed dam|url=http://www.burmanet.org/news/2013/05/03/democratic-voice-of-burma-karen-rebels-ordered-to-leave-area-near-thai-backed-dam/|accessdate=2013-05-03|newspaper=Burmanet News|date=2013-05-03}}</ref>
Numerous environmental groups and local villagers have decried the project’s anticipated ecological and social impact.<ref name="above water">{{cite news|last=Naing|first=Saw Yan|title=Keeping their heads above water|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/print/364083/|accessdate=2013-05-03|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=2013-08-11}}</ref><ref name="genuine peace">{{cite news|last=DVB|title=KNU wants genuine peace before dam construction resumes|url=https://www.dvb.no/dvb-video/knu-wants-genuine-peace-before-dam-construction-resumes-burma-myanmar/38564|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=DVB|date=2014-03-17}}</ref> Criticisms have targeted the project's alleged lack of transparency,<ref name="genuine peace" /> damage to the environment,<ref name="ej atlas">{{cite web|title=Hatgyi Dam, Myanmar| url=http://www.ejatlas.org/conflict/hatgyi-dam-myanmar|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> disruption of peace negotiations between the [[Karen National Union]] and the Myanmar Army, and impact on local communities, including displacement of local populations.<ref name="briefing">{{cite news|title=Briefing: Current Status of Dam Projects on Burma's Salween River|url=http://www.internationalrivers.org/resources/briefing-current-status-of-dam-projects-on-burma%E2%80%99s-salween-river-7868|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=International Rivers|date=2013-03-13}}</ref>
== Location == The dam site is in the Myaing Gyi Ngu area of the Hlaing Bwe Township in Myanmar's Karen State.<ref name="karen farmers">{{cite news|last=Ewar|first=Manight|title=Hatgyi Dam generates problems for Karen farmers|url=http://www.bnionline.net/index.php/feature/kic/10171-hatgyi-dam-genrates-problems-for-karen-farmers.html|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=Burma News International|date=2011-01-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503042335/http://bnionline.net/index.php/feature/kic/10171-hatgyi-dam-genrates-problems-for-karen-farmers.html|archivedate=2014-05-03|df=}}</ref> It is 33 kilometers downstream of the confluence of the [[Moei]] and Salween Rivers,<ref name="karen rebels" /> and about 47 kilometers from the Thai-Myanmar border.<ref name="briefing" /> It is opposite [[Mae Hong Son Province]] in northern Thailand.<ref name="karen farmers" /> The portion of the Salween at which the dam will be built features particularly strong rapids, which in the dry season become a waterfall. The dam site is also within the Kahilu Wildlife Sanctuary.<ref name="salween watch">{{cite web|title=Recent Dam and Water Diversion Plans|url=http://www.salweenwatch.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=51&Itemid=60#1|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref>
The areas surrounding the Hatgyi Dam site are ethnically diverse and ecologically rich. At least 13 different indigenous groups live along the Salween river,<ref name="karen rebels" /> and over ten million people are supported by the Salween River basin. The Salween's waters are nutrient-rich and support local vegetation and farmlands.<ref name="dammed by peace">{{cite news|last=Cambell|first=Charlie|title=Salween River Dammed by Peace|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/human-rights/salween-river-dammed-by-peace.html|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=The Irrawady|date=2012-03-07}}</ref>
== Details == The dam is being funded by the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT), a Thai government owned company which has built dams since 1964,<ref name="karen farmers" /> China's Sinohydro Corporation, and Myanmar's Ministry of Electric Power and International Group of Entrepreneurs (IGE), with Sinohydro holding the majority of shares, EGAT being the second largest shareholder, and Myanmar holding the fewest shares. IGE is owned by Nay Aung, son of [[Aung Thaung]], the central advisor for Myanmar's [[Union Solidarity and Development Party]].<ref name="ethnic armed groups">{{cite news|last=Maw|first=Khin Sett|title=Ethnic armed groups oppose Hatgyi dam project|url=http://elevenmyanmar.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5319:ethnic-armed-groups-oppose-hatgyi-dam-project&catid=44:national&Itemid=384|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=Eleven Myanmar|date=2014-03-09}}</ref>
The majority of the generated energy will be sent to Thailand,<ref name="karen rebels" /> which is looking to secure cheap energy supplies to replace its high reliance on natural gas. Currently, 70 percent of Thailand's energy comes from natural gas, the supply of which is expected to last only thirty years.
== History == === 1998-2007 === The project began in 1998 with a feasibility study titled, "Preliminary Feasibility Study of Hutgyi Hydropower Project in the Union of Myanmar". The study recommended the construction of a "a low height, run-of-river dam having a capacity of 300 MW". In November 2005, however, Thailand's energy minister cited a newer feasibility which stated that the dam could handle a capacity of up to 1,200 megawatts of power.<ref name="salween watch" />
In 2004, survey work began on the project. However, when two EGAT employees were killed in May of that year, one from a grenade and the other from a landmine, the project was halted. In December 2005, in preparation for a series of dam investments along the Salween River, a [[memorandum of understanding]] (MOU) was signed between Myanmar's Hydro Electric Power Department and Thailand's EGAT. In June of the following year, another memorandum of understanding was signed, which this time included Sinohydro, in addition to Myanmar and EGAT. Shortly thereafter, work commenced on road repairs near the dam site. In these MOUs, Myanmar and Thailand agreed to keep all data and joint studies on the dam "strictly confidential".<ref name="salween watch" />
Work on the project once again stalled when an EGAT staff member was killed in 2007. Work resumed on the project in 2008.<ref name="karen farmers" /> Looking at the concurrent developments in the region's ethnic conflicts, the Karen National Liberation Army Peace Council (KNLAPC), which was founded by the commander of the [[Karen National Liberation Army]]’s 7th Brigade, signed a peace agreement with Myanmar's State Peace and Development Council (SPDC) in February 2007.
=== 2008-2010 === In 2008, another MOU was signed, this time between Myanmar and Sinohydro, which established Sinohydro as the majority shareholder in the dam project. June 2009 saw another uptick in violence, as the DKBA and the army began an offensive against the KNU. Because of this offensive, around 4,000 Karen villagers were forced to flee their homes.<ref name="karen farmers" /> This was the largest refugee influx from Karen to Thailand in over a decade.<ref name="briefing" />
Across the border during the same year, Thailand's Office of the Prime Minister formed a subcommittee to look into and monitor the potential human rights impacts of the Hatgyi project.<ref name="briefing" /> In 2010, the subcommittee recommended more extensive studies on the local impacts of the dam project, focusing especially on the impact of the project on Thailand. The recommendation claimed the existing environmental impact assessment (EIA) did not focus enough on the implications of the project for Thailand.<ref name="dammed by peace" /> Nothing ever came of these recommendations, however.<ref name="briefing" />
Since the 1990s, when it broke off from the Christian-dominated Karen National Union, the Democratic Karen Buddhist Army had been cooperating with the Myanmar Army. However, in 2010, Saw La Pwe formed an anti-government breakaway faction of the DKBA.<ref name="karen rebels" />
=== 2011-present === Public hearings regarding the construction of the dam were held in the [[Sop Moei District]] of northern Thailand in 2011. Attendance was high.<ref name="briefing" /> In December of that year, the Karen National Union reluctantly agreed to allow further surveys to be conducted for the dam.<ref>{{cite web|title=Investors Haste to Build Big Dams is Undermining Fragile Peace Process in Karen State| url=http://www.burmapartnership.org/2012/03/investors-haste-to-build-big-dams-is-undermining-fragile-peace-process-in-karen-state/|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> In January of the following year, a temporary ceasefire was signed between the national army and the KNU. Only two months later, however, there was a noticeable build-up of army troops in the area around the dam site.<ref name="briefing" />
Around this time, Jin Honggen, economic and commercial counselor at China's Myanmar embassy, related the concern of many Chinese investors at the lack of progress in a variety of investment projects, including the Hatgyi Dam. He stated that, "some Chinese companies in Myanmar, especially those investing in resource fields, are worrying their interests can't be secured".<ref>{{cite news|last=Jincui|first=Yu|title=Wooing old customers anew|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/746784.shtml|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=Global Times|date=2012-11-22}}</ref>
In late-February 2013, Myanmar's deputy minister of electric power told parliament that the Hatgyi Dam was one of six dams whose construction had been approved.<ref name="briefing" /> Less than two months later, in April, local villagers first reported visible evidence of the project getting underway, claiming that EGAT was setting up water measurement posts at the Hatgyi Dam site.<ref name="knu protests">{{cite news|last=Su Nyar|first=Saw Khar|title=KNU protests as EGAT marks Salween River Hat Gyi dam site|url=http://karennews.org/2013/05/knu-protests-as-egat-marks-salween-river-hat-gyi-dam-site.html/|accessdate=2014-05-03|newspaper=Karen News|date=2013-05-20}}</ref> At the same time, Myanmar's military presence in the area was as high as ever, as witnesses reported the presence of eight army battalions near the dam site.<ref name="tension">{{cite web|title=China-backed dams escalating ethnic tension in Myanmar|url=https://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/5823-Chinese-dams-escalating-ethnic-tension-in-Myanmar|accessdate=2014-03-05}}</ref> Meanwhile, the DKBA was forced to evacuate the dam area in May.<ref name="karen rebels" /> As of September 2014, troop deployments to the dam site continued in order to increase security.<ref>{{cite web|title=Troops deployed near Thanlwin dam site|url=http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7657:troops-deployed-near-thanlwin-dam-site&catid=44:national&Itemid=384|publisher=Eleven Myanmar|accessdate=16 November 2014|date=24 September 2014}}</ref>
== Controversy == === Impact on local populations === Concerns about the impact of the dam on local populations have largely revolved around the displacement of numerous villages due to flooding, and the lack of involvement of local communities in the decision-making process.
In 2013, the Karen National Union explained to local villagers that nine Karen villages would be flooded and damaged as a result of the Hatgyi Dam.<ref name="knu protests" /> Karen Rivers Watch (KRW) pegs the number of displaced villages at 21.<ref name="above water" /> EJ Atlas estimates the potential affected population to range from 1,000 to 30,000 local residents, with listed impacts including displacement, loss of livelihood, and loss of culture.<ref name="ej atlas" /> Saw Kyaw Phoe of Mae Par Village explained: "If the dam is built, our village, the whole area, including our paddy farms and our gardens will be flooded. I, myself, will have no place to live."<ref name="karen farmers" />
An open letter written by Karen Rivers Watch in 2011 stated that the dam would only exacerbate problems associated with the displacement of war-torn communities, with very little benefit actually being received by the local community, as the majority of the power generated by the dam would be exported.<ref name="open letter">{{cite web|title=Burma Partnership; An Open Letter in Support of the President of Myanmar's Decision on the Suspension of the Myitsone Dam Project and a Call for a Review of the Hatgyi Dam Project in Kayin (Karen) State|url=http://www.burmapartnership.org/2011/10/an-open-letter-a-call-for-a-review-of-the-hatgyi-dam-project-in-kayin-karen-state/|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref>
Paul Sein Twa, director of the Karen Environmental and Social Action Network (KESAN) pointed out that, "Local people do not want any dams on the Salween River, especially in Karen State, without the free, prior and informed consent of impacted communities." <ref name="tension" /> Along those lines, the aforementioned KRW open letter expressed that there had been "little consultation with affected communities" and that the majority of the local populations opposed the dam.<ref name="open letter" />
The higher military presence in the area associated with the construction and maintenance of the Hatgyi Dam has also been a source of concern and criticism. Naw Paw Gay, of the KRW, explained that, "the presence of the Burmese troops will lead to more human rights abuses." Saw Kyaw Phoe, meanwhile, while commenting on the negative implications of increased troops in the area to protect the dam, related that the Myanmar army would, "force villagers to carry their food ration and ammunition and to lead Burmese troops through land mined areas."<ref name="karen farmers" />
=== Disruption of peace negotiations === [[International Rivers]] claims that the dam project has been obstructing peace negotiations between the Karen National Union and the Myanmar Army.<ref name="briefing" /> Likewise, the Democratic Karen Buddhist Army's tactical operations commander Colonel Saw Maung Kyar explained that, "problems will get worse if [the government] starts increasing the military forces by using the dam as an excuse." Meanwhile, the joint secretary of the Karen National Union, P'Doh Saw That Thi Bwe, argued that, "the Hatgyi hydropower project is located in our land. Our stand is not to allow such kind of big project until we have a guarantee for discussing politics."<ref name="ethnic armed groups" />
=== Environmental impact === Environmental researcher Steve Thompson of the Karen Environmental and Social Action Network (KESAN) commented on the Hatgyi Dam by explaining that the dam could, "wipe out many or most riverine fish species, with serious socio-economic consequences for local villagers".<ref name="above water" /> An open letter by the Karen Rivers Watch in 2011 described the Hatgyi Dam site as being in an "ecologically sensitive area", close to an [[active fault]] line.<ref name="open letter" /> EJ Atlas listed environmental impacts as including flooding, biodiversity loss, soil, pollution, and deforestation.<ref name="ej atlas" />
==References== {{reflist|2}}
