web|url=http://www.economie.gouv.fr/agence-participations-etat/Les-participations-publiques|title=Les participations publiques |date=30 April 2015|access-date=21 February 2016|publisher=Agence des participations de l'État|language=French}} Moreover, [[Électricité de France]] of which the French government has a majority ownership stake, owned 2.24%; [[Kuwait Investment Authority]] owned 4.82% as the second largest shareholder after the French state.{{cite web|url=http://www.areva.com/finance/liblocal/docs/doc-ref-2014/DDR_EN_310315.pdf|title=2014 Reference document|date=30 March 2015|access-date=21 February 2016|publisher=Areva}} In 2017 the majority of its reactor business [[Framatome]] (previously Areva NP) was sold to [[Électricité de France]], while Areva will quit the new company ("New NP") by 2020. [[Japan Nuclear Fuel Limited]] and [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]] will take a 5% stake each in another new company, which will run the nuclear fuel business of Areva, later named Orano (previously "NewCo").{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsgreen-light-for-areva-restructuring-5734608 |title=Green light for Areva restructuring |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=8 February 2017 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/news-10939/decision-to-no-longer-publish-quarterly-financial-information.html |title=AREVA has decided not to publish quarterly financial information anymore |accessdate=2017-03-31 |publisher= Areva S.A. Press Release}} On 23 January 2018 Areva was renamed '''Orano'''. ==History== ===Creation of Areva=== [[File:Siege Areva 33 rue Lafayette P1050953.JPG|upright|thumb|Former Areva headquarters, rue Lafayette in Paris]] Areva was created on 3 April 2001, by the [[merger]] of [[Framatome]] (later Areva NP, now sold off and renamed back to Framatome), [[Cogema]] (now [[Areva NC]]) and Technicatome (now Areva TA). It was based on the structure of its precursor, CEA-Industrie, and [[Anne Lauvergeon]] was named CEO.{{cite web|title=Stock Ownership Profile |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/finance-402/shareholding-structure-of-the-world-leader-in-the-nuclear-industry-and-major-player-in-bioenergies.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} In 2009, Siemens sold its remaining shares of Areva NP.Marc Lomazzi, ''Le Parisien'', 13 August 2007 [http://www.leparisien.fr/economie/nucleaire-les-dessous-de-l-accord-entre-la-france-et-la-libye-13-08-2007-2008285886.php' "Nucléaire: les dessous de l'accord entre la France et la Libye"] {{fr icon}}. {{cite news | title = Siemens to give up nuclear joint venture with Areva | publisher = [[Helsingin Sanomat]] | date = 27 January 2009 | url = http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Siemens+to+give+up+nuclear+joint+venture+with+Areva/1135243067027 | accessdate = 6 January 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121020234153/http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Siemens+to+give+up+nuclear+joint+venture+with+Areva/1135243067027 | archivedate = 20 October 2012 | df = dmy-all }} {{cite news | title = Siemens quits the nuclear game | publisher = [[World Nuclear Association#Public information|World Nuclear News]] | date = 19 September 2011 | url = http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/C_Siemens_quits_the_nuclear_game_1909111.html | accessdate = 6 January 2013}} [[Jean-Pierre Raffarin]], the former [[Prime Minister of France]], government announced the privatization of Areva in 2003, but it was postponed several times, the French government opting finally for the privatization of GDF and EDF. At the end of October 2005, French Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin announced that he had suspended the privatization process. In 2006, Areva created its Renewable Energies Business Group.{{cite web|title=Renewable Energy, Expected Growth |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/group-689/renewable-energies-expected-growth.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} Creusot Forge and Creusot Mécanique merged into the Areva group,{{cite web |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-2119/creusot-forge-and-creusot-mcanique-manufacturer-of-large-forged-parts-history.html |title=Creusot Forge and Creusot Mécanique: the production of large forged parts - History |publisher=Areva |accessdate=3 March 2017}} even though there were quality concerns over Creusot Forge's work.{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsasn-warned-about-creusot-forge-over-10-years-ago-5781134 |title=ASN warned about Creusot Forge over 10 years ago |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=6 April 2017 |accessdate=10 April 2017}} In March 2010, Areva indicated work was being done on a new type of [[burner reactor]] type capable of breaking down [[actinides]] created as a product of [[nuclear fission]].Robin Pagnamenta, The Times, 22 March 2010, [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/news/areva-develops-new-nuclear-reactors-that-destroy-atomic-waste/story-e6frg90o-1225843555348 Areva develops new nuclear reactors that 'destroy' atomic waste], The Australian Due to financial difficulties in 2016, in 2017 Areva NP merged with and as of January 04, 2018, Areva NP is now known as Framatome. ===Post-[[Fukushima nuclear disaster|Fukushima]] problems=== In December 2011, Areva suspended building work at several sites in France, Africa and the United States, one day after forecasting a €1.6 billion ($2.1 billion) loss. Areva halted "capacity extensions" at its [[COGEMA La Hague site|La Hague Reprocessing Plant]], in northern France, at its Melox factory in the southwest, and at two sites attached to its Tricastin power plant in the south. Work has also stopped on extensions to uranium mines in Bakouma in the Central African Republic, Trekkopje in Namibia, and Ryst Kuil in South Africa,{{cite web |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hKI_2Q1_VI8EUXiKo-K7hlVuhFgg?docId=CNG.5611f082b5d1d0d543b2b015f4ad2b41.841 |title=French nuke giant Areva suspends investment in sites |date=14 December 2011 |work=AFP }} and caused a potential delay in construction until a capital solution is secured for the [[#Eagle Rock Enrichment Facility|Eagle Rock Enrichment Facility]] in the United States.{{cite web |url=http://us.arevablog.com/2011/12/13/areva-continues-eagle-rock-commitment/ |title=Areva Continues Eagle Rock Commitment |date=13 December 2011 |work= }} Areva wrote off most of the $2.5 billion purchase cost of Canadian uranium mining company Uramin, purchased in 2007, after concluding that its uranium ore deposits were of negligible value. In September 2014 [[Standard & Poor's]] stated it might downgrade Areva’s debt following weak first-half results, leading to Areva indicating it would cut capital spending and dispose of some assets.{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/adc90b3e-6f67-11e4-8d86-00144feabdc0.html |title=EDF in fresh delay for flagship nuclear plant |author=Michael Stothard |newspaper=Financial Times |date=18 November 2014 |accessdate=21 November 2014}} In October 2014, CEO Luc Oursel took a leave of absence for health reasons. He died in December of the same year.{{cite web|last1=Landauro|first1=Inti|title=Areva CEO Luc Oursel Dies|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/areva-ceo-luc-oursel-dies-1417678416|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=5 December 2014}} On 19 November 2014 Areva suspended its financial targets for 2015/2016 as a result of delays on its Finnish project ([[Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant]] Unit 3) and "lacklustre" nuclear market.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-30114326 |title=Areva shares plunge after it drops financial targets |publisher=BBC |date=19 November 2014 |accessdate=21 November 2014}} As a result, on 20 November 2014 Standard & Poor's downgraded Areva long-term debt to BB+ and short-term-debt to A-3.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/21/markets-factors-europe-idUSL6N0TB0DO20141121 |title=European Factors to Watch-Indexes to edge higher, focus on ECB speeches |publisher=Reuters |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=23 November 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/fastft/239772/areva-cut-junk-sandp |title=Areva cut to junk by S&P |publisher=fastFT |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=25 November 2014}} This led to difficulties for Areva to raise money on the financial market, however according to S&P Areva has a "high cash cushion". Some analysts speculate that Areva needs a 1.5-2 billion euro capital increase – at the moment the French government ([[Second Valls Government]]) is unwilling to increase capital for the state-owned company.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/28/areva-debt-idUSL6N0TH31X20141128 Areva's options narrow in shadow of debt refinancing] Reuters The balance sheet 2014 shows a sales revenue of 8.336 bn Euro and a [[consolidated net income]] of -4.834 bn Euro (0,58 Euro loss per 1 Euro sales revenue).areva.com [http://areva.com/scripts/news/publigen/content/templates/Show.asp?P=10470&L=EN 2014 Annual Results (group)] (4 march 2015) In March 2015 [[Standard & Poor's]] further downgraded Areva's [[credit rating]] to BB- after Areva posted a €4.8 billion loss for 2014. Areva intends to cut costs to save about €1 billion annually by 2017, and to sell €450 million of assets by 2017.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/03/06/areva-ratings-idUKL5N0W81MR20150306 |title=UPDATE 1-S&P downgrades Areva debt further into junk status |author=Geert De Clercq |publisher=Reuters |date=6 March 2015 |accessdate=6 March 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/05/business/international/areva-plans-to-cut-costs-while-mastering-difficult-projects.html |title=Areva Plans to Cut Costs While Mastering 'Difficult Projects' |author=David Jolly |newspaper=New York Times |date=4 March 2015 |accessdate=6 March 2015}} The French government is considering a rescue plan which may include some form of bailout from [[Électricité de France]] (EDF).{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-16/france-s-areva-falters-in-reactor-business-leaks-cash |title=Areva Is Costing France Plenty |author=Carol Matlack |publisher=Bloomberg |date=16 April 2015 |accessdate=21 April 2015}} In May, Areva announced that it expected to cut 5,000 to 6,000 jobs out of its 42,000 employees globally.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/05/07/uk-areva-employment-idUKKBN0NS0I420150507 |title=Areva says to cut 5,000-6,000 jobs globally |author=Geert De Clercq |publisher=Reuters |date=7 May 2015 |accessdate=10 May 2015}} In July 2015, EDF agreed to a majority stake in Areva NP.http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/C-EDF-agrees-to-majority-stake-in-Arevas-reactor-business-3007156.html [[Bernard Fontana]] has been appointed CEO of Areva NP as of 1 September 2015. On October 31st 2015, it was announced that [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]] would be taking an equity stake in Areva NP (up to 34 percent), possibly eventually extending it to one in Areva as a whole.{{cite news|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/business/AJ201510310044 |title=Mitsubishi Heavy to buy stake in French nuclear giant's reactor subsidiary |author= |publisher=[[Asahi Shimbun|''The Asahi Shimbun'']] |date=31 October 2015 |accessdate=1 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107192002/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/business/AJ201510310044 |archivedate=7 November 2015 }} MHI decided to take this step because of Areva NP's vital role in their [[Atmea]] reactor [[joint venture]]. In July 2015 EDF valued Areva NP at €2.7 billion ($2.9 billion) and agreed to take a majority stake in Areva NP, following a French government instruction they create a "global strategic partnership".{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsedf-to-buy-majority-of-areva-np-4635803 |title=EDF to buy majority of Areva NP |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=31 July 2015 |accessdate=20 May 2016}} ===Le Creusot Forge records falsification scandal=== In December 2015, operations at Le Creusot Forge were stopped following the discovery of quality assurance problems.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-ASN-sets-conditions-for-Creusot-Forge-restart-1804175.html |title=ASN sets conditions for Creusot Forge restart |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=18 April 2017 |accessdate=21 April 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsfrench-regulator-lists-conditions-for-operation-of-le-creusot-forge-5791213 |title=French regulator lists conditions for operation of Le Creusot Forge |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=20 April 2017 |accessdate=21 April 2017}} Following a discovery at the [[Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant]], about 400 large steel forgings manufactured by Le Creusot Forge since 1965 have been found to have carbon-content irregularities that weakened the steel. A widespread programme of reactor checks was started involving a progressive programme of reactor shutdowns, likely to continue over the winter high electricity demand period into 2017. This caused power price increases in Europe as France increased electricity imports, especially from Germany, to augment supply.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/f86a3c6c-9c60-11e6-a6e4-8b8e77dd083a |title=French nuclear outages threaten higher UK power bills |author=Andrew Ward |newspaper=Financial Times |date=28 October 2016 |accessdate=2 November 2016}}{{cite report |url=http://www.greenpeace.org/france/PageFiles/266171/Note_LargeAndAssociates_EN_26092016.pdf |title=Irregularities and Anomalies Relating to the Forged Components of Le Creusot Forge |author=John Large |work=Large Associates |publisher=Greenpeace France |date=26 September 2016 |accessdate=27 October 2016}} As of late October 2016, 20 of France's 58 reactors are offline.{{cite news |url=http://www.powermag.com/frances-nuclear-storm-many-power-plants-down-due-to-quality-concerns/?printmode=1 |title=France's Nuclear Storm: Many Power Plants Down Due to Quality Concerns |author=Lee Buchsbaum |newspaper=POWER |date=1 November 2016 |accessdate=2 November 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-france-power-winteroutlook-idUKKBN1332C6 |title=France could face winter power cuts, hit by nuclear dependence |author=Bate Felix, Geert De Clercq |publisher=Reuters |date=8 November 2016 |accessdate=11 November 2016}} These steel quality concerns may prevent the regulator giving the life extensions from 40 to 50 years, that had been assumed by energy planners, for many reactors.{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21711087-electricit-de-france-has-had-shut-down-18-its-58-nuclear-reactors-frances-nuclear-energy |title=France's nuclear-energy champion is in turmoil |newspaper=The Economist |date=3 December 2016 |accessdate=3 December 2016}} In December 2016 the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' characterised the problem as a "decades long coverup of manufacturing problems", with Areva executives acknowledging that Le Creusot had been falsifying documents.{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/problems-at-nuclear-components-supplier-spark-global-reviews-1481625005 |title=Coverup at French Nuclear Supplier Sparks Global Review |author1=Matthew Dalton |author2=Inti Landauro |author3=Rebecca Smith |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=13 December 2016 |accessdate=15 December 2016}} In December 2016 international inspectors at Le Creusot Forge found evidence of recent doctored paperwork, which had not been detected by Areva’s independent quality control checks. The team concluded that they "were not confident that the improvement programmes and associated remedial actions ... were sufficiently resourced, prioritised and integrated in order to bring about sustained improvements in manufacturing performance and nuclear safety culture".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/mar/24/areva-creusot-nuclear-forge-france-hinkley-point |title=Inspectors find safety irregularities at Creusot nuclear forge in France |first=Adam |last=Vaughan |newspaper=The Guardian |date=24 March 2017 |accessdate=24 March 2017}} In March 2017 [[Autorité de sûreté nucléaire]] (ASN) determined that the safety culture in the plant was not sufficient to produce nuclear components and that the plant did not have sufficiently good equipment for some of its nuclear production, which led to the manufacture of substandard parts and document falsification.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/areva-safety-creusot/areva-factory-ill-equipped-to-make-nuclear-parts-french-watchdog-idUSL5N1GM2XM |title=Areva factory ill-equipped to make nuclear parts - French watchdog |publisher=Reuters |date=16 March 2017 |accessdate=8 February 2018}} In April 2017 ASN published the requirements for forging to resume at Le Creusot Forge. In August 2017 ASN published a draft decision requiring the examination of Le Creusot Forge manufacturing records of all components during scheduled reactor refuelling outages.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-EDF-ordered-to-check-component-records-1708174.html |title=EDF ordered to check component records |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=17 August 2017 |accessdate=18 August 2017}} On 25 January 2018 ASN gave approval for the resumption of the manufacture of forgings at Le Creusot. The 2016 improvement plan was 90% complete and will complete during the first half of 2018. The forge had been out of operation since December 2015. "Irregularities" in records of about 400 of 3854 nuclear components produced since 1965 had been found, and analysis of these deviations were expected to continue until the end of 2018.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-Le-Creusot-to-resume-manufacture-of-forgings-26011801.html |title=Le Creusot to resume manufacture of forgings |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=26 January 2018 |accessdate=8 February 2018}} ===Recent developments=== In June 2016 Areva's restructuring plans were made public, including the sale of the majority of its reactor business to EDF in 2017, excluding the [[Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant|Olkiluoto 3 EPR]] under construction in Finland which will remain with Areva SA.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/C-Areva-outlines-restructuring-plan-1506164.html |title=Areva outlines restructuring plan |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=15 June 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} On 1 March 2017 Areva published figures for 2016 (loss 665 million Euro) and announced some information about the planned restructuring.[http://www.areva.com/FR/actualites-10923/resultats-annuels-2016.html www.areva.com] On 21 March 2017 [[Japan Nuclear Fuel Limited]] (JNFL) and [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]] (MHI) agreed to each take a 5% stake in the restructured Areva nuclear reactor business for €250 million each, dependent on the [[Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant|Flamanville 3]] [[reactor pressure vessel]] and other large steel forgings passing safety tests.{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsinvestment-agreements-on-areva-newco-take-effect-5770314 |title=Investment agreements on Areva NewCo take effect |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=23 March 2017 |accessdate=28 March 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/features/featurenuclear-cracks-are-beginning-to-show-5768266/ |title=Nuclear cracks are beginning to show |author=Janet Wood, Caroline Peachey |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=21 March 2017 |accessdate=28 March 2017}} Some days later, [[Toshiba]]'s nuclear branch ([[Westinghouse Electric Company]]) filed for [[Chapter 11]] bankruptcy protection. In December 2017, Areva and EDF signed agreements on the transfer of Areva NP's nuclear reactor operations.http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/C-Binding-agreements-signed-for-sale-of-New-NP-2712175.html On 23 January 2018 Areva was renamed '''Orano'''. The name Areva shall continue to be used only relating to the holding company Areva SA, that is holding risks associated with Olkiluoto and the troubled Creusot foundry. The company's new circular yellow logo refers to [[yellowcake]] uranium concentrate and to the nuclear fuel cycle.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/areva-name/media-areva-to-be-renamed-orano-les-echos-idUSL8N1PH64T |title=Areva to be renamed Orano-Les Echos |author=Geert De Clercq |publisher=Reuters |date=23 January 2018 |accessdate=12 February 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-areva-strategy/frances-areva-rebrands-to-orano-in-dire-uranium-market-idUSKBN1FC25H |title=France's Areva rebrands to Orano in dire uranium market |author=Geert De Clercq |publisher=Reuters |date=23 January 2018 |accessdate=12 February 2018}} ==Business lines== Areva is an international company in [[nuclear power|nuclear]] and [[renewable energy|renewable]] energy.{{cite web|title=French Nuclear Giant Buys Calif. Solar Startup |url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2010/02/09/09greenwire-french-nuclear-giant-buys-calif-solar-startup-83791.html |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=3 June 2014}} It is the only company with a [[Vertical integration|presence in each industrial activity]] linked to nuclear energy: [[uranium mining|mining]], chemistry, enrichment, fuel assembly, reprocessing, engineering, nuclear propulsion and reactors, treatment, recycling, stabilization and dismantling. Areva offers technological solutions for [[carbon dioxide|CO₂]]-free energy partly through Areva Renewables.{{cite web|title=The Renewable Energies Business Group at a Glance |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-395/the-renewable-energies-business-group-at-a-glance.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014}} Areva’s activities are divided into 5 Business Groups:{{cite web|title=Areva’s Operations |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-57/operations-entire-nuclear-energy-cycle-and-renewable-energies.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} * Mining: combines operations related to uranium exploration, extraction, processing and reclamation of sites. *Front End: encompasses uranium conversion and enrichment, nuclear fuel design and production.{{cite web|title=The Front End Business Group |url= http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-704/front-end-of-the-nuclear-cycle-uranium-conversion-and-enrichment-fuel-design.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014}} *Reactors and Services: designs and builds nuclear power plants, naval propulsion reactors and research reactors, and manufactures related equipment.{{cite web|title=The Reactors and Services Business Group |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-1669/reactors-services-nuclear-reactors-power-plant-services.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014}} * Back End: manages all operations in the back end of the nuclear cycle, from used nuclear fuel recycling to the dismantling and value development of nuclear facilities.{{cite web|title=The Back End Business Group |url= http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-1135/back-end-used-nuclear-fuel-treatment-and-recycling-mox-fabrication.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014}} * Renewable Energies: develops and manages a portfolio of operations revolving around 4 renewable energies: wind energy, bioenergy, solar power, and hydrogen power, as well as energy storage.{{cite web|title=The Renewable Energies Business Group |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-404/renewable-energies-wind-solar-biomass-hydrogen-and-energy-storage.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014}} Areva’s subsidiary for power transportation and distribution, Areva T&D, was sold to [[Schneider Electric]] and [[Alstom]] in June 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/will-split-areva-td-into-two-separate-entities-alstom_535741.html |title=Will split Areva T&D into two separate entities: Alstom |publisher=MoneyControl.com |date=3 June 2014}} Current subsidiaries include Euriware and SAFRAN. ===Mining Business Group=== The Mining Business Group manages the exploration of uranium ore, its extraction, and processing, as well as the restoration of sites after mine closure.{{cite web|title=The Mining Business Group at a Glance |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-5631/the-mining-business-group-at-a-glance.html|publisher=Areva |accessdate=23 June 2014}} Areva’s Mining Business Group has staff on five continents and operates uranium production sites in Canada, Kazakhstan, and Niger.{{cite web|title=Mining Business Group Worldwide |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-658/worldwide-mining-operations-meeting-demand-for-uranium-through-global-operations.html|publisher=Areva |accessdate=23 June 2014}} As of the end of 2013, the Mining Business Group employed 4,463 people.{{cite web|title=2013 Reference Document |url=http://www.areva.com/mediatheque/liblocal/docs/groupe/Document-reference/2013/DDR_AREVA_2013_EN.pdf |publisher=Areva |accessdate=23 June 2014}} Uranium production accounted for 19 percent of Areva's consolidated revenue in 2013. ===Front End Business Group=== The Front End Business Group secures access to fuel for Areva’s customers, and oversees operations to convert uranium into nuclear fuel, including the chemical conversion of ore into uranium hexafluoride, the enrichment of uranium, and the design and production of fuel for nuclear reactors.{{cite web|title=The Front End Business Group at a Glance |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-708/the-front-end-business-group-at-a-glance.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=23 June 2014}} As of the end of 2013, 8,555 people worked for Areva’s Front End Business Group. The Business Group accounted for 24 percent of Areva’s consolidated revenue. In 2013, the Front End Business Group saw a 6.8 percent revenue increase to $3 billion.{{cite web|title=Mining bolsters Areva's 2013 revenues |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/C-Mining-bolsters-Arevas-2013-revenues-3101144.html |publisher=World Nuclear News |accessdate=24 June 2014}} The Front End Business Group is divided into two main business units: *The Chemistry and Enrichment Business Units, which were previously, separate units of the Front End Business Group, merged to become one at the start of 2013. On the Chemistry side, the Unit focuses on converting natural uranium into uranium hexafluoride. The Enrichment side of the Unit supplies clients with enrichment services. *The Fuel Business Unit is responsible for fuel design and production, and markets fuel-related engineering services. It markets conventional enriched uranium oxide fuel as well as MOX fuel and enriched reprocessed uranium fuel. ===Reactors & Services Business Group=== The Reactors & Services Business Group designs and builds Pressurized Water Reactors (PWR) and Boiling Water Reactors (BWR). The Business Group also designs and builds naval propulsion and research reactors and offers products to service nuclear reactors. The Business Group had 15,592 employees at the end of 2013 and generated 36 percent of Areva’s revenue in the same year. It is split into six business units: *New Builds Business Unit: Handles design and construction of new nuclear reactors *Installed Based Business Unit: Offers products for existing nuclear reactors *Propulsion & Research Reactors Business Unit: Focuses on naval propulsion and research reactors *Equipment Business Unit: Manufactures components for the nuclear steam supply system *Products & Technology Business Unit: Manages the standardization and certification of nuclear products and technologies *Nuclear Measurements Business Unit: Develops and markets systems to detect and measure radioactivity ===Back End Business Group=== The Back End Business Group develops recycling solutions for used fuel for reuse in reactors. It also offers storage and transportation solutions for radioactive material, and site rehabilitation at nuclear facilities. At the end of 2013, the Business Group had 11,583 employees and made up for 19 percent of Areva’s revenue. Based in Europe and North America, the Back End Business Group is divided into five Business Units: *Recycling Business Unit – helps customers recycle 96% of used fuel into fresh fuel *International Projects Business Unit – develops the Business Group’s facilities for international markets *Dismantling & Decommissioning Business Unit – designs and oversees the dismantling and rehabilitation of nuclear sites *Cleanup Business Unit – operates waste treatment and decontamination facilities and maintenance logistics *Logistics Business Unit – design and production of equipment to transport and store nuclear materials, and organization of nuclear material transportation In 2017 the NUHOMS Matrix advanced [[Dry cask storage|used nuclear fuel storage]] overpack, a high-density system for storing multiple spent fuel rods in canisters, was launched.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/WR-Arevas-space-saving-solution-for-used-fuel-storage-2909175.html |title=Areva's space-saving solution for used fuel storage |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=29 September 2017 |accessdate=29 September 2017}} ===Renewable Energies Business Group=== Areva created its global Renewable Energies Business Group in 2006 as an expansion of its [[clean energy]] portfolio with [[renewable energy]]. This group represents four business lines: [[concentrated solar power]], offshore [[wind power]], [[biomass]] power, and hydrogen power storage and distribution. The Renewable Energies Business Group has offices in the United States, Brazil, India and France. ====Concentrated Solar Power==== In February 2010, Areva formed Areva Solar with its acquisition of US-based [[Ausra (company)|Ausra]],{{cite web|url=http://www.infogrok.com/index.php/energy/areva-to-acquire-ausra.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212110801/http://www.infogrok.com/index.php/energy/areva-to-acquire-ausra.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 February 2010 |title=Areva To Acquire Ausra |publisher=InfoGrok |accessdate=25 January 2009 }} a provider of concentrated solar power solutions using [[Compact Linear Fresnel Reflector]] (CLFR) technology.{{cite web| url=http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/01/deals-accumulating-for-solar-startup/| title=Deals Accumulating for Solar Start-up| publisher=The New York Times| accessdate=29 May 2014}} Headquartered in Mountain View, California, Areva Solar operates a 5[[MWe]] solar power plant in Bakersfield, California, at its [[Kimberlina Solar Thermal Energy Plant]] development facility.{{cite web|title=Areva Solar Kimberlina Solar Power Plant & Research Facility |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/solar-164/areva-solar |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} Areva Solar markets its solar boiler technology in three formats: as a standalone solar power plant generating 50MW+ of electricity, as a solar booster (20-50MW) adding solar steam power to an existing fossil-fuel power plant for carbon mitigation, and as an industrial steam provider for food, oil, [[desalination]] and other processes.{{cite web|url=http://www.fresnonewenergy.com/ABOUT/OurPartners/AREVA.aspx |title=Areva |publisher=Fresno At its [[Bremerhaven]], Germany manufacturing facility, Areva Wind produces 5MW [[wind turbine]]s specifically designed and sealed for offshore environments. The company designs, manufactures, assembles and commissions its wind turbines and blades for offshore wind projects, notably in the [[North Sea]]. In the summer of 2009, AREVA Wind installed the first 6 M5000 turbines of the [[Alpha Ventus Offshore Wind Farm|Alpha Ventus]] project in the [[North Sea]].{{cite web| url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-3606/areva-wind-energy-solutions.html| title=Alpha Ventus: An Offshore Pilot Project Already Producing Electricity | publisher=Areva| accessdate=9 June 2014}} These are located about 45 kilometers from the German island of Borkum, at a depth of 30 meters. This new biomass plant concept also aims to improve upstream technologies for multi-fuel acceptance and higher availability. ====Energy storage==== AREVA designs, manufactures and industrializes turnkey energy storage solutions and products to generate electricity with fuel cells and produce hydrogen by electrolysis. AREVA supports ongoing research in the hydrogen field through partnerships with a number of industrial companies and national research organizations including: [[Agence Nationale de la Recherche]] (French National Research Agency), the Horizon Hydrogen Energy (H2E) program, PAN-H (''Plan d’Action National sur l’Hydrogène et les piles à combustible'') and Pôle Capenergies, an innovation cluster dedicated to the development of renewable forms of energy without greenhouse gas emissions.{{cite web|url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-407/areva-energy-storage.html |title=AREVA Energy Storage |publisher=Areva |accessdate=9 June 2014}} In 2012, Areva inaugurated a hydrogen storage system called the MYRTE platform near [[Ajaccio]], Corsica (MYRTE is the French acronym for ''Mission Hydrogène Renouvelable pour l’intégration au réseau électrique'').{{cite web|url=http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/hydrogen-storage-site-for-photovoltaic-power-2012-02-10 |title=Areva unveils hydrogen storage system |publisher=Engineering News |accessdate=11 June 2014}} The system aims to establish the feasibility of a storage solution for [[solar energy]] using hydrogen technologies, which would serve as a back-up system to stabilize Corsica’s power grid. In 2014, AREVA’s energy storage and management system, the Greenergy Box, was added to the existing installation, in operation since early 2013. This management system increases grid output from the energy stored in hydrogen to 150 kW.
