Areva's [[Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization|EBITDA]] for 2013 (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation) was 1.04 billion euros.{{cite web|title=Areva shares plunge after loss, problems in Finland |url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/140227/areva-shares-plunge-after-loss-problems-finland |publisher=Global Post |accessdate=30 May 2014 }} The consolidated backlog stood at 41.5 billion euros at December 31, 2013, down from 44.6 billion euros a year earlier.{{cite web|title=2013 Annual Results Press Release |url=http://www.areva.com/news/liblocal/docs/CP_groupe/2014/2014022620-%20CP%20AREVA%20RA%202013%20VUK.pdf |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} ===2014=== Nuclear sales declined for Areva after the 2011 Japanese [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima disaster]], and this was also the case for rival nuclear companies such as [[General Electric]] and [[Westinghouse Electric]]. Areva had a €4.8 billion loss in 2014 on sales of 8.3 billion euros.Carol Matlack, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-16/france-s-areva-falters-in-reactor-business-leaks-cash Areva is costing France plenty], ''Bloomberg Businessweek'', April 17, 2015. ==Nuclear reactor designs== [[File:EPR OLK3 lage.jpg|thumb|EPR generic layout]] [[File:OL3.jpg|thumb|right|[[Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant|Olkiluoto-3]] under construction in 2009]] === EPR === {{Further|EPR (nuclear reactor)}} ==== Finland ==== In December 2003, [[Finland]] became the first country to order a new [[nuclear reactor]] in Western Europe in 15 years{{cite web|title=Finland Rekindles Interest in Nuclear Power |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/12/international/europe/12finland.html |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=28 May 2014 }} – it will become [[Nuclear power in Finland|Finland]]'s fifth reactor.{{cite web|title=Country Profile Finland |url=http://www.oecd-nea.org/general/profiles/finland.html |publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] [[Nuclear Energy Agency|NEA]] |accessdate=28 May 2014 }}{{cite web|title=OLKILUOTO 3 - FINLAND |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-2389/finland--olkiluoto-3.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} Areva started construction of the first [[European Pressurized Reactor]] (EPR) in [[Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant|Olkiluoto]] in 2005.{{cite web|title=In Finland, Nuclear Renaissance Runs Into Trouble |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/29/business/energy-environment/29nuke.html |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=28 May 2014 }} The reactor, which is one of the first of the new [[Generation III reactor]]s, was initially expected to begin producing electricity in 2009, but the project has faced delays.{{cite web|title=Finnish Nuclear Plant Won’t Open Until 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/12/business/global/finnish-nuclear-plant-wont-open-until-2016.html |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} In 2003 Finland’s [[Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant|Olkiluoto]] contract was issued on a [[turnkey]] basis and in 2004 a contracted fixed price was established as €3200M. Over the years delays have accumulated and costs started to overrun substantially. In its 2006 Annual Report, Areva recorded a write-down of €507M associated with the delay. {{As of|2014}} the project is at least seven years behind schedule with a total cost estimate of €8.5 billion ($11.4 billion).{{cite web|title=UPDATE 1-Finnish nuclear plant delayed again as Areva, TVO bicker |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/02/28/tvo-olkiluoto-idUKL6N0LX3XQ20140228 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=28 May 2014 }} According to the customer's estimate, the Olkiluoto plant will be finished by 2016. Owner TVO had originally contracted to start selling nuclear power at the end of April 2009.[http://www.worldwatch.org/system/files/pdf/WorldNuclearIndustryStatusReport2011_%20FINAL.pdf Nuclear Power in a Post-Fukushima World] The world nuclear industry status report 2010–2011 World Watch page 8, 28, 30, 60, 62 ==== France ==== A second [[European Pressurized Reactor|EPR]] is currently under construction at the [[Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant]] in France.[http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/newNuclear/Construction_of_Flamanville_EPR_begins-041207.shtml World-nuclear-news.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213091503/http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/newNuclear/Construction_of_Flamanville_EPR_begins-041207.shtml |date=13 February 2008 }} As of 2014, this plant is behind schedule and over-budget.{{cite web|title=French Disconnection: Reacting to nuclear cost curse |url=http://reneweconomy.com.au/2014/french-disconnection-reacting-to-nuclear-cost-curse-30460 |publisher=Renewable Economy |accessdate=28 May 2014 }} The reactor is set to generate its first power in 2017. ==== China ==== In November 2007, Areva agreed to a €8 billion deal with the [[China Guangdong Nuclear Power Group]] to supply them with two EPRs in [[Taishan, Guangdong|Taishan]], [[Guangdong]], China.{{cite web|title=European companies sign deals to supply China with airplanes and nuclear power |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/26/business/worldbusiness/26iht-trade.4.8485444.html |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=28 May 2014}} Under the terms of the agreement, Areva will also help operate the plant, including the reprocessing of spent fuel.John Tagliabue, ''[[New York Times]]'', 27 November 2007 [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/27/business/worldbusiness/27nuke.html "China Deal Gives Lift to Revival of Fission"]. The nuclear reactor in Taishan is projected to cost less and be built more quickly following lessons learned in Finland.{{cite web|title=China Builds Nuclear Reactor for 40% Less Than Cost in France, Areva Says |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-24/china-builds-french-designed-nuclear-reactor-for-40-less-areva-ceo-says.html |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=11 June 2014}} ===Atmea I=== The [[Atmea]] I is a new evolutionary [[Generation III reactor]] design targeted towards both developed and developing economies. It is a joint venture between Areva and [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]].{{cite web|url=http://www.atmea-sas.com/scripts/ATMEA/publigen/content/templates/show.asp?P=140&L=EN |title=The ATMEA company offers the ATMEA1 reactor - a mid-sized Generation III+ PWR (Pressurized Water Reactor) |publisher=ATEMA |accessdate=3 June 2014}} The design is for a PWR with a power output of about 1,100 MWe.{{cite web|url=http://www.atmea-sas.com/scripts/ATMEA/publigen/content/templates/show.asp?P=163&L=EN |title=A new mid-sized Generation III+ reactor |publisher=ATEMA |accessdate=3 June 2014}} Plans called for the design to be ready for licensing applications by the end of 2009.[http://www.atmea-sas.com/ ATMEA-SAS.com], Retrieved on 25/06/09 The [[Sinop Nuclear Power Plant|first is expected to be built in Turkey]] with construction set to begin by 2017 or after, and completed by 2023 or after. === Kerena === In 2009, Areva announced that its 1,250 MWe Generation III+ [[boiling water reactor]] (BWR) design, provisionally known as SWR-1000, will henceforth be called Kerena. The Kerena design was developed from that of the [[Gundremmingen Nuclear Power Plant]] by Areva, with extensive German input and using operating experience from [[Generation II reactor|Generation II]] BWRs to simplify systems engineering.{{cite web | url= http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Areva_names_its_BWR-1803097.html | title= Areva names its BWR | date= 20 March 2009 | work= [[World Nuclear News]] | publisher= | accessdate= 20 March 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090322034359/http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Areva_names_its_BWR-1803097.html| archivedate= 22 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} == Worldwide presence == Worldwide, the Areva group has an industrial presence in 43 countries and its commercial network reaches more than 100 countries.{{cite web| url=http://www.areva.com/EN/group-727/partner-to-the-world-s-power-companies-with-offices-around-the-globe.html| title=Balanced International Implementation| publisher=Areva| accessdate=4 January 2012}} As of 2013, it employed approximately 45,340 people.{{cite web| url=http://areva.com/EN/group-3870/groupekey-figures2013-key-figures.html| title=2013 Key Figures| publisher=Areva| accessdate=9 June 2014}}{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/areva/| title=Areva Company Profile| publisher=Forbes| accessdate=11 June 2014}} In 2006, ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' reported that Areva was the "Most Admired Global Energy Company."[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/globalmostadmired/snapshots/4081.html CNNMoney] Areva has partnered with engineering contractors to aid in the [[reconstruction of Iraq]] by manufacturing equipment to construct electrical substations.[http://www.symbion-power.com/experience/sub_farabi.html Farabi and Jamila, Iraq Substations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929012011/http://www.symbion-power.com/experience/sub_farabi.html |date=29 September 2007 }} In 2007, AREVA purchased [[UraMin]], which later became Areva Resources Southern Africa. ===Areva in Europe=== ====UK==== Areva in the UK provides services for nuclear reactor design and construction, as well as related services.{{cite web|url=http://uk.areva.com/EN/home-579/areva-uk-your-local-actor-in-nuclear-and-renewable-energy-industry.html |title=Leader in Low Carbon Power Generation for the UK |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140705123743/http://www.uk.areva.com/EN/home-579/areva-uk-your-local-actor-in-nuclear-and-renewable-energy-industry.html |archivedate=5 July 2014 }} The Business Group also offers renewable technologies, including offshore wind and bioenergy.{{cite web|url=http://uk.areva.com/EN/home-542/renewable-energy-areva-investment-in-england-areva-uk.html |title=Areva's Renewable Offer in the UK |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140615035311/http://uk.areva.com/EN/home-542/renewable-energy-areva-investment-in-england-areva-uk.html |archivedate=15 June 2014 }} *[[Sellafield]]: In 2008, Areva was awarded an operations contract to clean up the Sellafield nuclear reprocessing site as part of the Nuclear Management Partners consortium, made up of URS, Amec and Areva. Sellafield, located in Cumbria, England, is western Europe’s largest and most complex nuclear waste site.{{cite web| url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/39671bba-2cf5-11e3-a0ac-00144feab7de.html#axzz34i5IEqur | title=Nuclear Management Partners Wins Extension to Clean up Sellafield | publisher=The Financial Times| accessdate=24 June 2014}} *[[Hinkley Point C nuclear power station|Hinkley Point C]]: In October, 2013, Areva won a $2.7 billion contract to supply two EPR nuclear reactors and control systems to the Hinkley Point C plant in [[Somerset]], England. Areva has a 10% stake in the project, and will supply the nuclear steam supply system, the instrumentation and control system, and the fuel. Other partners on the project include France’s [[EDF Energy|Électricité de France]] (EDF), the [[China General Nuclear Power Group]] (CGN), and the [[China National Nuclear Corporation]] (CNNC).{{cite web|url=http://uk.areva.com/EN/home-440/areva-s-nuclear-eprnbsp-projects-in-great-britain-areva-uk.html |title=Two EPR Reactor's at EDF's Hinkley Point |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140705162421/http://www.uk.areva.com/EN/home-440/areva-s-nuclear-eprnbsp-projects-in-great-britain-areva-uk.html |archivedate=5 July 2014 }}{{cite web| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-10-21/areva-secures-u-k-reactor-order-worth-more-than-2-7-billion.html | title=Areva Secures U.K. Reactor Order Worth More Than $2.7 Billion | publisher=Bloomberg| accessdate=24 June 2014}} The Hinkley plant will be the first nuclear power plant built in Britain since the [[Sizewell nuclear power stations|Sizewell B]] in Suffolk, which started electricity production in 1995.{{cite web| url=http://news.sky.com/story/1157272/hinkley-point-nuclear-plant-deal-to-go-ahead | title=Hinkley Point Nuclear Plant Deal To Go Ahead | publisher=Sky News| accessdate=24 June 2014}} The Hinkley Point C plant is projected to cut CO2 emissions in the UK by 9 million tons a year and create 25,000 construction jobs and 900 operations jobs. ===Areva in Africa=== ==== Niger ==== [[File:MineArlit1.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Open-pit mining|open pit]] [[Uranium mining|uranium mine]] at Arlit, Niger.]] Areva operates two mines through SOMAÏR and COMINAK situated in [[Arlit]], in northern [[Niger]], and is also developing the Imouraren project situated 80 km from Arlit.{{cite web|title=Special Report: Areva and Niger's uranium fight |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/05/us-niger-areva-specialreport-idUSBREA140AA20140205 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 May 2014 }} These mines and projects employ more than 7,000 people. Niger is the world's fourth largest uranium producer.{{cite web|title=Uranium in Niger |url=http://world-nuclear.org/info/Country-Profiles/Countries-G-N/Niger/ |publisher=World Nuclear Association |accessdate=27 May 2014 }} Up until 2007, Areva was the only industrial company able to extract uranium in the country, but under a policy shift by then President [[Mamadou Tandja]], the field was opened to competition and [[China Nuclear International Uranium Corporation|Sino-U]], a Chinese nuclear energy company, was granted uranium concessions.{{cite news|last=Burgis|first=Tom|title=Uranium: Coup alters the balance as nations jostle for position|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/93e487c6-74ed-11df-aed7-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2c4QZdYNA|newspaper=The Financial Times|date=June 14, 2010}} On 25 July 2007, the CEO of Areva-Niger, Dominique Pin, was expelled from Niger (although he was in Paris at the time) on charges of supporting the [[Tuareg rebellion (2007–2009)|Tuareg Rebellion]]."Atomes pas très crochus au Niger" in ''Le Canard enchaîné'', 22 August 2007, p. 4 {{fr icon}}. The ''Financial Times'' described the entry of Sino-U in 2007 as a "battle for resources" between China and France and illustrated a competition view held by some that saw "China’s pursuit of Africa’s resources as a direct – and potentially destabilizing – threat to western interests". The country manager for AREVA disagreed with this view, stating in the same article that there were many uranium blocks, sufficient to keep both companies busy. The population of Niger was exposed to a serious [[famine]] in 2005. AREVA donated €130,500 from January to June 2005 to the food crisis coordination group of Niger, and €120,000 in July in the form of two planes loaded with food and organized by [[Bernard Kouchner]]'s ''Réunir'' NGO.{{cite web|title=Fight Against Famine in 20015 |url= http://niger.areva.com/EN/niger-229/fight-against-famine-in-2005.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=22 May 2014 }} In November 2009, Greenpeace released a report indicating that two villages near AREVA's mining operations in Niger had dangerously high levels of radiation.[http://www.rfi.fr/actuen/articles/120/article_6057.asp RFI.fi][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ioRtzOWm07A&feature=digest Left in the Dust – uranium mining in Niger] // GreenpeaceVideo. [[YouTube]]. To restore the information about AREVA’s mining activities in Niger, AREVA published a report answering in complete transparency to all the accusations made by the NGO. {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} {{npov|date=October 2018}} In May 2013, the firm’s SOMAÏR uranium mine was damaged and one civilian was killed in an [[Al-Qaeda]]-linked suicide bomb attack, targeting the firm on the grounds that it was a French-owned company.{{cite web|title=Niger attacks launched from southern Libya: Niger's president |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCABRE94O08I20130525 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 May 2014 }} The mine reached full production again in August 2013.{{Citation | url = http://www.miningweekly.com/article/areva-niger-mine-back-at-full-production-after-islamist-attack-2013-08-07 | title= Areva Niger mine back at full production after Islamist attack | year = 2013 | publisher = [[Mining Weekly]] | publication-place = [[South Africa]]}}{{cite web |title=AREVA: At September 30, 2013: Backlog of €42bn |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/24/areva-idUSnBw246420a+100+BSW20131024 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528005221/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/24/areva-idUSnBw246420a+100+BSW20131024 |archivedate=28 May 2014 |df=dmy-all }} ====Namibia==== Areva is present in [[Namibia]] through its subsidiary AREVA Resources Namibia. The Group's uranium mining project in Namibia at Trekkopje was put on hold in 2012 due to a decrease in uranium prices following the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster.{{cite web|title=Areva delays $1 bln Namibia uranium mine |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/11/areva-namibia-trekkopje-idUSL6E8LBL4C20121011 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=24 June 2014 }}{{cite web|title=Areva delays $1 bln Namibia uranium mine |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/11/ozabs-areva-namibia-trekkopje-idAFJOE89A02120121011 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} Areva is currently running a care and maintenance program at the site so that it can be reopened in the future. The program is run at a cost of $10 million per year.{{cite web|title=Areva Resources Namibia: More than Just Mining |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-595/areva-resources-namibia-training-and-mining-projects.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} At the end of 2013, Areva directly employed about 50 people in Namibia, as well as about 50 suppliers and contractors in the country. Areva Resources Namibia finished a 20 million cubic meter desalination plant in the semi-arid Erongo region of the country in 2010.{{cite web |title=Areva Namibia-Unit Water Deal to Ensure Supply for Rio, Paladin |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/11/ozabs-areva-namibia-trekkopje-idAFJOE89A02120121011http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-06-05/areva-namibia-unit-water-deal-to-ensure-supply-for-rio-paladin |publisher=Business Week |accessdate=24 June 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In June 2014, AREVA announced plans to sign a 10-year deal with state-run utility Namibia Water Corp to maintain water supplies essential to uranium mines in the country. ====Gabon==== Areva has had a presence in Gabon since the 1950s, although there is currently no uranium mining in the country.{{cite web|title=Uranium Hot Spots: Mauritania, Gabon and Zambia |url=http://uraniuminvestingnews.com/17496/uranium-gabon-mauritania-zambia-africa.html |publisher=Uranium Investing News |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} Today, Areva operates in the country under the subsidiary Areva Gabon, established in 2008. Areva Gabon is focused on exploring new mining possibilities at sites around the country.{{cite web|title=Areva Gabon: Discovering New Deposits |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-585/areva-gabon-discovering-new-deposits.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} Gabon has received mineral exploration permits in four areas: Mopia, Andjogo, Lekabi, and N’Goutou. In 2010, Areva launched the Mounana Health Observatory to treat former workers who became ill after working in the COMUF mine, which was shut down in 1999.{{cite web|title= Areva, Gabon launch plan to help ill uranium workers |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/10/19/gabon-areva-idAFLDE69I2L220101019 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} ==== Libya ==== On 13 August 2007, the French newspaper ''[[Le Parisien]]'' alleged that the [[Libya and nuclear technology|Franco-Libyan civil nuclear power agreement]] signed by President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] did not concern desalinization of sea water, as claimed by the French government, but instead focused in particular on selling the EPR to Libya, a contract potentially worth $3 billion. ''Le Parisien'' cited Philippe Delaune, deputy to the deputy director of international affairs for the [[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique|CEA atomic agency]], which is the main share-holder in Areva. Following allegations that the deal had been related to the [[HIV trial in Libya|release of the Bulgarian nurses]], the [[French Socialist Party]], through the spokesperson [[Jean-Louis Bianco]], declared that this deal was "geopolitically irresponsible". The [[German government]] also denounced the agreement. ===Areva in North America=== ==== Canada ==== {{Further|Uranium mining in Canada|Areva Resources Canada}} Areva Resources Canada Inc., created in 1993, is a uranium mining, milling, and exploration company based in [[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]].{{cite web|title=Areva Resources Canada: From Exploration to Decomissioning |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-593/exploration-and-mining-of-uranium-in-canada.html# |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} Areva Resources Canada has offices and operations in Saskatoon, La Ronge, McClean Lake, Cluff Lake, and in Baker Lake, Nunavut. *[[McClean Lake mine|McClean Lake]]: Located over 700 kilometres northeast of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, open pit mining began in 1995 and was suspended with the completion of the Sue ore bodies in 2008.{{cite web|title=Site Guide: McClean Lake Operation |url=http://us.areva.com/home/liblocal/docs/Operations/Mining/McClean_Lake_Site_Guide2.pdf |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|title=McClean Lake |url=http://www.denisonmines.com/s/McLean_Lake.asp |publisher=Denison Mines |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} The JEB mill at McClean Lake was recently expanded and upgraded to process ore from other projects, including Cigar Lake. Processing began at the mine in March 2014.{{cite web|title=Issues at McClean Lake Mine |url=http://www.wise-uranium.org/umopmcl.html#MCCLEANLEXPCIGARL |publisher=Wise Uranium |accessdate=25 June 2014 }}{{cite web|title=Areva says uranium production begins at Cameco's Cigar Lake mine |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/13/areva-cameco-idUSL6N0MA32M20140313 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} The McClean Lake operation meets ISO 14001 standards for environmental management, as well as OHSAS 18001 for occupational health and safety management.{{cite web|title=McClean Lake Operation |url=http://www.saskmining.ca/commodity-info/Commodities/35/uranium.html |publisher=Saskatchewan Mining Association |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} *[[Cluff Lake mine|Cluff Lake]]: In 2002, the [[Cluff Lake mine]] reached the end of its uranium production. The Cluff Lake mine produced 62 million pounds of yellowcake over a 22-year period.{{cite web|title=The return of Cluff Lake today's mine decommissioning practice |url=http://www.leaderpost.com/business/return+Cluff+Lake+today+mine+decommissioning+practice/9873145/story.html |publisher=Leader Post |accessdate=25 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911090722/http://www.leaderpost.com/business/return%2BCluff%2BLake%2Btoday%2Bmine%2Bdecommissioning%2Bpractice/9873145/story.html |archivedate=11 September 2014 |df=dmy }} Since mining ceased, Areva Resources has implemented a decommissioning program to rehabilitate the site.{{cite web |title=Cluff Lake |url=http://us.areva.com/EN/home-983/areva-resources-canand-activities.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011083007/http://us.areva.com/EN/home-983/areva-resources-canand-activities.html |archivedate=11 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }} Most of the decommissioning was completed in 2006 after two years of work to fill the open pits, demolish the mill, cover the tailings management area, and reslope and cover waste rock piles. Over 800,000 trees have been planted in this effort. The Cluff Lake operation meets ISO 14001 standards for environmental management. ==== United States ==== {{Further|Nuclear power in the United States}} Areva operates as Areva Inc. in the USA, and is present in more than 35 locations across 20 states, employing nearly 5,000 people.{{cite web |title=Areva in the US |url=http://us.areva.com/EN/home-99/areva-in-the-us.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223164952/http://us.areva.com/EN/home-99/areva-in-the-us.html |archivedate=23 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }} Areva Inc. supplies network products to two-thirds of all US utilities.{{cite web |title=Areva Well Placed to Advance Smart Grid Initiative |url=http://us.areva.com/EN/home-1265/areva-inc-press-release.html' |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} Areva Inc.'s headquarters are located in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]].{{cite web |title=Areva Expanding in Charlotte with North American Headquarters Relocation, Additional Engineering Jobs |url=http://us.areva.com/EN/home-2206/areva-inc-areva-inc-relocating-to-charlotte-nc.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} In February 2002, the [[U.S. Secretary of Energy]] [[Spencer Abraham]] announced the [[Nuclear Power 2010 Program]], which included plans for two [[European Pressurized Reactor|EPR]]s. This private/public partnership aimed to develop advanced reactor technologies and deploy new nuclear power plants by 2010,{{cite web |title=Nuclear Power 2010 Program Overview |url=http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/Presentation%20-%202010%20Program%20Overview%20-%20Presentation%20to%20the%20NEAC.pdf |publisher=Nuclear Energy Research Advisory Committee |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} when the program was completed.{{cite web |title=US Nuclear Policy |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Country-Profiles/Countries-T-Z/USA--Nuclear-Power-Policy/ |publisher=World Nuclear Association |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} On 15 September 2005, Areva and [[Constellation Energy]] of Baltimore announced a [[joint venture]] called [[UniStar Nuclear]] to market the commercial [[European Pressurized Reactor|EPR]] in the US.{{cite web |title=EPR: Constellation Energy and Areva Join Forces to Introduce New and Unique Business Model for the Future of American Nuclear Power |url=http://us.areva.com/EN/home-892/areva-inc-press-release.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} The joint venture later became [[Unistar|UniStar Nuclear Energy]] in 2007. In 2010, EDF acquired 100 percent of UniStar Nuclear Energy.{{cite web |title=Constellation/EDF UniStar nuclear timeline |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/10/15/utilities-constellation-edf-idUSN1522147220101015 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} However these plans failed to come to fruition, and in February 2015 Areva suspended the EPR Design Certification Application Review process at the U.S. [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] (NRC).{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-US-EPR-plans-suspended-0603157.html |title=US EPR plans suspended |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=6 March 2015 |accessdate=21 April 2015}} =====Eagle Rock Enrichment Facility===== Areva Inc., based in [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], announced on May 6, 2008 that it would seek all necessary approval to build a [[uranium]] [[Nuclear enrichment|enrichment]] facility in Bonneville County, [[Idaho]], about twenty miles west of [[Idaho Falls]] and near the [[Idaho National Laboratory]],{{cite news|title=Areva selects enrichment site |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=8 May 2008 |url=http://89.151.116.69/NN-Areva_selects_US_enrichment_site_070508.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080718060818/http://89.151.116.69/NN-Areva_selects_US_enrichment_site_070508.html |archivedate=18 July 2008 |df=dmy }}[http://www.areva.com/servlet/cp_06_05_2008-c-PressRelease-cid-1209581724309-en.html Areva – Press : press releases] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512082558/http://www.areva.com/servlet/cp_06_05_2008-c-PressRelease-cid-1209581724309-en.html |date=12 May 2008 }} with the proposed name of Eagle Rock Enrichment Facility (EREF).[http://www.areva.com/servlet/vdg_eagle_08_04_2008-c-AroundUs-cid-1217613609516-en.html Areva.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821161503/http://www.areva.com/servlet/vdg_eagle_08_04_2008-c-AroundUs-cid-1217613609516-en.html |date=21 August 2008 }} Areva had officially announced plans for a US enrichment facility already since 2007.{{cite news|title=Areva's American enrichment plan |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=29 June 2007 |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/explorationNuclearFuel/Areva_s_American_enrichment_plan_290607.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014051254/http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/explorationNuclearFuel/Areva_s_American_enrichment_plan_290607.shtml |archivedate=14 October 2008 |df=dmy }}{{cite web |title=Areva Eagle Rock Enrichment Facility project (Bonneville County, Idaho, USA) - Current Issues |url=http://www.wise-uranium.org/epusarc.html |publisher=WISE Uranium Project |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} The Eagle Rock plant was expected to provide uranium enrichment services to US nuclear plant operators using advanced proven centrifuge technology developed by the Enrichment Technology Company Ltd. (ETC), an Areva/[[Urenco]] joint venture. In 2010, EDF acquired 100 percent of UniStar Nuclear Energy. In December 2011, as part of an Areva investment freeze, the company announced a potential delay in construction until a capital solution was secured for the Eagle Rock Enrichment Facility. It is now budgeted at $3 billion,{{cite web |title=Areva mum on date for Idaho nuke plant |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/765630492/Areva-mum-on-date-for-Idaho-nuke-plant.html?pg=all |publisher=Desert News |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} has a US [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] license and a $2 billion loan guarantee from the [[United States Department of Energy|Energy Department]]. In May 2013, Areva announced that it no longer projects a date for building the Eagle Rock plant because of uncertainties regarding its financing.{{cite web |title=Eagle Rock Enrichment Plant |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/operations-779/the-eagle-rock-project-construction-of-an-enrichment-plant-in-the-united-states.html# |publisher=Areva |accessdate=25 June 2014 }} ===Areva in Asia=== ==== South Korea ==== {{Further|Nuclear power in South Korea}} In 2007, Areva signed a ten-year deal with the South Korean public company [[KHNP]] to enrich uranium at its [[Georges Besse II enrichment plant]],''[[Reuters]]'', 19 June 2007 [https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSSE036400720070619 "S. Korea signs uranium enrichment deal with France"] which was inaugurated in 2010. The deal is worth over €1 billion. In November 2013, Areva and South Korea electric utility [[Korea Electric Power Corporation|KEPCO]] signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate in the renewable energy sector,{{cite news| url=http://renewables.seenews.com/news/french-areva-s-korea-kepco-to-cooperate-in-renewable-energy-387833 | work=SeeNews | title=French Areva, S Korea Kepco to cooperate in renewable energy | date= 6 November 2013 }} with a particular focus on biomass in Southeast Asia.{{cite news| url=http://asian-power.com/project/more-news/areva-and-kepco-will-cooperate-in-renewable-energy | work=Asian Power | title=Areva and Kepco will cooperate in renewable energy | date= 12 November 2013 }} ==== China ==== In China, Areva won an €8 billion ($11.9 billion) agreement in 2007 to build nuclear reactors.{{cite web |title=Areva, Airbus Lead $30 Billion Haul in China Visit (Update3) |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=apreTFF295OE |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=25 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627075926/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive |archivedate=27 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }} [[Anne Lauvergeon|Lauvergeon]] said the deal enables allows Areva to "consolidate its presence in one of the most dynamic markets in the world with enormous potential.”{{cite web |title=France's Areva finalizes $11.9 billion sale of 2 nuclear reactors to China |url=http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/business/20071126-0110-china-france-nuclear.html |publisher=UT San Diego |accessdate=25 June 2014}} The third-generation pressurized water reactors boosted state-run [[China General Nuclear Power Corporation|China Guangdong Nuclear Power Corporation]]’s (CGNPC) output by 3,400 megawatts. The contract also called on Areva to provide uranium to fuel the reactors through 2026. The [[European Pressurized Reactor|EPR]] reactors are expected to begin commercial operation in 2015{{cite web |title=France’s EPR Nuclear Reactor to Get Chinese Debut, Minister Says |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-11-12/france-s-epr-nuclear-reactor-to-get-chinese-debut-minister-says.html |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=25 June 2014}} in the city of Taishan in Guangdong province, an export manufacturing powerhouse with heavy demand for power and high levels of industrial pollution.[http://www.mercurynews.com/healthandscience/ci_7562266?nclick_check=1 Mercurynews.com] ===== CPR-1000 ===== The [[China General Nuclear Power Corporation]] has enhanced the [[Nuclear power in France#900 MWe class|French 900 MWe]] three-cooling-loop design imported in the 1990s into the 1,000 MWe [[CPR-1000]] design.{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf63.html |title=Nuclear Power in China |publisher=World Nuclear Association|date=2 July 2010|accessdate=18 July 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100731142459/http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf63.html| archivedate= 31 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} Some intellectual property rights are retained by Areva, which limits CPR-1000 export potential for China.{{cite web |title=Nuclear Power in China |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Country-Profiles/Countries-A-F/China--Nuclear-Power/ |publisher=World Nuclear Association |accessdate=25 June 2014}} Areva is reported to be considering whether it should market the cheaper, less sophisticated, CPR-1000 alongside the EPR, for countries that are new to nuclear power.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/00767364-0175-11df-8c54-00144feabdc0.html|title=Areva considers producing cheaper reactors|author=Peggy Hollinger|date=15 January 2010|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=19 January 2010}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fd5ee326-dbb9-11df-a1df-00144feabdc0.html |title=Energy: Cooling ambitions |author=Peggy Hollinger |date=19 October 2010 |publisher=Financial Times |accessdate=29 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101023013011/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fd5ee326-dbb9-11df-a1df-00144feabdc0.html| archivedate=23 October 2010| deadurl= no}} In December 2013, Areva and [[China General Nuclear Power Group|China General Nuclear Power]] (CGN) agreed to a partnership in renewable energy, with a focus on offshore wind, biomass, concentrated solar power, and energy storage.{{cite web |title=CORRECTED-Areva signs energy partnership agreements in China |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/12/09/areva-china-idUKL6N0JO0XX20131209 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=25 June 2014}} ====India==== On 18 December 2008, Areva signed an agreement with the [[Nuclear Power Corporation of India Limited]] (NPCIL) for the supply of 300 tonnes of uranium to India for power generation,{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a9_A7IkXbJYA | work=Bloomberg | title=India Chooses AREVA as Its First Foreign Uranium Supplier | date=18 December 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150916205622/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive | archivedate=16 September 2015 | df=dmy-all }} thus becoming the first-ever foreign supplier of Uranium to the country after the NSG waiver.{{cite news| url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2011/07/india-unfazed-by-nuclear-suppliersrsquo-new-rules/ | work=IPS News | title=INDIA: Unfazed by Nuclear Suppliers’ New Rules | date= 6 July 2011 }} On 4 February 2009, Areva signed an MOU to supply two to six nuclear reactors to the [[Nuclear Power Corporation of India Limited]], for the [[Jaitapur Nuclear Power Project]] in the Indian state of Maharashtra.{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/interview/article911058.ece | work=The Hindu | title=‘We are partners over the long haul' | date= 25 November 2010 }} The deal is thought to be worth around 8 billion Euro ($10.4 billion).{{cite news| url=http://in.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idINIndia-37842220090204?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 | work=Reuters | title=Areva wins India nuclear deal worth at least $10 bln | date=4 February 2009}} ==== Kazakhstan ==== In June 2008, Areva reached an agreement with [[Kazatomprom]]. The collaboration lead to the creation of a joint-venture Katco which provides 4000 uranium's tones per year. Due to that contract [[Kazakhstan]] became one of the three most important partnerships for the group.{{cite web|url=http://www.areva.com/EN/news-6636/areva-and-kazakhstan-sign-a-strategic-agreement-in-the-front-end-of-the-nuclear-cycle.html|title=Areva and Kazakhstan Sign a Strategic Agreement in the Front End of the Nuclear Cycle|work=areva.com|date=11 June 2008}} ==Notable incidents== ===2007 fine=== In January 2007, Areva was fined €53 million by the [[European Commission]] for [[Price fixing cases|rigging]] EU electricity markets through a [[cartel]] involving 11 companies, including [[ABB Group|ABB]], [[Alstom]], [[Fujifilm|Fuji]], [[Hitachi Japan]], [[AE Power Systems]], [[Mitsubishi Electric Corp]], [[Schneider Electric]], [[Siemens]], [[Toshiba]] and VA Tech ELIN.[http://www.euractiv.com/en/energy/eu-cracks-electricity-gear-cartel/article-161169 EU cracks down on electricity-gear cartel], ''[[EurActiv]]'', 25 January 2007 . According to the Commission, "between 1988 and 2004, the companies rigged bids for procurement contracts, fixed prices, allocated projects to each other, shared markets and exchanged commercially important and confidential information." Siemens was given a fine of €396 million, more than half of the total, for its alleged leadership role in the cartel. Areva is not accused of any cartel involvement other than through the acquisition of an Alstom unit in January 2004. "This subsidiary was acquired by the Areva group towards the end of the infringement, in January 2004. The parent entities of the Areva group share a joint liability with that subsidiary for the period after its acquisition."[http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/07/80&format=HTML&aged=1&language=EN&guiLanguage=fr Competition: Commission fines members of gas insulated switchgear cartel over 750 million euros] IP/07/80 Brussels, 24 January 2007, Press Releases – EUROPA "A few months before the cartel ended, Alstom sold the unit involved to Areva, which knew nothing of the cartel. It [Areva] and Alstom have joint liability for 53.6 million, which they must decide how to split."{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/sphereNews/idUSL2477822220070125?sp=true&view=sphere | work=Reuters | title=EU shocks electric cartel with 750 million euro fine | first=David | last=Lawsky | date=25 January 2007}} [[EU Competition Commissioner]] [[Neelie Kroes]] declared that "The commission has put an end to a cartel which has cheated public utility companies and consumers for more than 16 years".[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6296985.stm Vote call by Siemens shareholders], ''[[BBC]]'', 25 January 2007 ===Bakouma assault=== On 24 June 2012, an armed group assaulted a uranium plant operated by Areva at [[Bakouma]] in the southeast of the [[Central African Republic]]. A statement by the military described that "a violent clash on Sunday afternoon pitted" Central African troops against "an unidentified group of armed men attempting to launch an assault on the site of mining company Areva". According to the report the army successfully repelled the attack, but "the enemy did some material damage and pulled back while taking a sizeable quantity mainly of food with them." The Areva group issued no immediate statement regarding the attack. Central African military sources believe that the attack was organized by members of the [[Chad|Chadian]] rebel group [[Popular Front for Recovery]] (FPR) led by 'General' Baba Ladde, which has been active in the region since 2008. The army says it's conducting further operations to neutralize the remaining armed rebels in the region of Bakouma.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/thetimes/2012/06/25/gunmen-attack-french-uranium-plant|title=Gunmen Attack French Uranium Plant|date=25 June 2012|work=timeslive.co.za}}{{cite web | title=CAR gunmen attack French uranium plant | website=News24 | date=2012-06-25 | url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/CAR-gunmen-attack-French-uranium-plant-20120625 | access-date=2018-03-11}} ===Tuareg people=== In January 2014, [[Al Jazeera]] produced ''[[Orphans of the Sahara]]'', three-part series on the [[Tuareg people]] of the Sahara desert, in which claims were brought to light that Areva mining and consequent radiations are causing diseases and deaths among their people.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/Orphans-of-the-Sahara/|title=Orphans of the Sahara: Exile|date=23 January 2014|author=Orphans of the Sahara channel|work=aljazeera.com|publisher=Al Jazeera}} Al Jazeera also published Areva’s response, in which the company said it submits regular reports on its environmental monitoring of water, air and soil to the Nigerien Office of Environmental Assessments and Impact Studies (BEEEI) which indicate that there is no pollution around the sites in question.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/orphans-of-the-sahara/2014/01/uranium-mining-niger-areva-responds-2014121101952629572.html|title=Uranium mining in Niger: AREVA responds|author=Orphans of the Sahara channel|publisher=Al Jazeera|work=aljazeera.com|date=23 January 2014}} ==Sport sponsoring== Areva has sponsored several sporting events over the years. *'''Track and Field''': In 2009, Areva launched Athlenergy.com, an online resource for runners,{{cite web|title=Athlenergy.com: The New Website for Track & Field and Running Enthusiasts |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/news-8356/athlenergy-com-the-new-website-for-track-and-field-and-running-enthusiasts.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} and became the sponsor of the French Athletics Federation{{cite web|title=Areva Renews Its Partnership with the French Athletics Federation |url=http://www.areva.com/EN/news-9681/areva-renews-its-partnership-with-the-french-athletics-federation.html |publisher=Areva |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} and the official sponsor of [[Meeting Areva]], a track and field competition held annually at the [[Stade de France]] in Saint-Denis, France.{{cite web|title=DiamondLeague-Paris.com: The Website for Meeting Areva |url=http://www.diamondleague-paris.com/ |publisher=Meeting Areva |accessdate=26 June 2014 }} In May 2014, Athlenergy.com became [https://web.archive.org/web/20140425025205/http://www.arevarun.com/ Arevarun]. Areva also sponsors several running events, including the Paris Half Marathon{{cite web |title=SemideParis.com: The English-Language Website for the Paris Half Marathon |url=http://www.semideparis.com/us/sponsors.html |publisher=Paris Half Marathon |accessdate=26 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605210452/http://www.semideparis.com/us/sponsors.html |archivedate=5 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }} and Saintélyon, a night run from Sainte Etienne to Lyon, in France.{{cite web |title=SainteLyon.com |url=http://www.saintelyon.com/en/actualites/60th-edition-who-says-better-than-this/ |publisher=Saintélyon |accessdate=26 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130913234329/http://www.saintelyon.com/en/actualites/60th-edition-who-says-better-than-this/ |archivedate=13 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }} *'''FC Nürnberg''': In 2008, Areva signed a contract to sponsor the German football club [[FC Nürnberg]] until 2012.{{cite news| url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/areva_extends_with_1._fc_nuernberg_but_shrinks_package/ | work=SportsProMedia.com | title=Areva extends with 1. FC Nürnberg but shrinks package | date= 7 August 2012 }} The contract was completed in 2012.{{cite news|url=http://www.soccerex.com/industry-news/areva-powers-down-fc-nurnberg-backing/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140626111302/http://www.soccerex.com/industry-news/areva-powers-down-fc-nurnberg-backing/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 June 2014 |work=Soccerex.com |title=Areva powers down FC Nurnberg backing |date=9 August 2012 }} *'''[[America's Cup|America’s Cup]]''': Areva sponsored the French “Defi Areva” team in the 2002 [[America’s Cup]] race, and the French “Areva Challenge” team in the 2007 America’s Cup race. In 2002, during its first public appearance, in Lorient, France, the “Defi Areva” yacht collided with a dinghy carrying four Greenpeace protesters, and the impact knocked a hole in the side of the 80-foot boat.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2002/may/20/sailing | work=The Guardian | title=French America's Cup yacht struck by Greenpeace protesters | date= 20 May 2002 }}{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/1394720/French-Americas-Cup-yacht-holed-in-Greenpeace-protest.html | work=The Telegraph | title=French America's Cup yacht holed in Greenpeace protest| date= 19 May 2002 }} ==See also== {{Portal|Paris|Companies|Energy|Nuclear technology}} * [[Calvert Cliffs Nuclear Power Plant]] * [[European Atomic Energy Community]] * [[Groupe INTRA]] * [[Kazatomprom]] * [[Nine Mile Point Nuclear Generating Station]] * [[Nuclear Power 2010 Program]] * [[World Nuclear Industry Status Report]] === Sites === * [[Tri-Cities, Washington]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.orano.group}} {{Nuclear power in France}} [[Category:Areva| ]] [[Category:Companies based in Paris]] [[Category:Companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Wind turbine manufacturers]] [[Category:French brands]] [[Category:Solar energy companies of the United States]] [[Category:Conglomerate companies of France]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in France]] [[Category:State-owned companies of France]] [[Category:Uranium mining companies of South Africa]]

{{Hatnote|Not to be confused with [[plasmaron]]. For the brand of dried milk biscuit, see [[Plasmon biscuit]].}} {{Condensed matter physics|expanded=Quasiparticles}} {{Technical|date=March 2015}}
In [[physics]], a '''plasmon''' is a [[quantum]] of [[plasma oscillation]]. Just as [[light]] (an optical oscillation) consists of [[photons]], the plasma oscillation consists of plasmons. The plasmon can be considered as a [[quasiparticle]] since it arises from the quantization of plasma oscillations, just like [[phonon]]s are quantizations of mechanical vibrations. Thus, plasmons are collective (a discrete number) oscillations of the [[Free electron model|free electron gas]] density. For example, at optical frequencies, plasmons can [[Coupling (physics)|couple]] with a [[photon]] to create another quasiparticle called a plasmon [[polariton]].
== Derivation == The plasmon was initially proposed in 1952 by [[David Pines]] and [[David Bohm]]<ref>David Pines, David Bohm: ''A Collective Description of Electron Interactions: II. Collective vs Individual Particle Aspects of the Interactions'', Phys. Rev. 85, 338, 15 January 1952. Cited after: {{cite book|author1=Dror Sarid|author2=William Challener|title=Modern Introduction to Surface Plasmons: Theory, Mathematica Modeling, and Applications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rXU1OLdjFUsC&pg=PA1|date=6 May 2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-76717-0|pages=1}}</ref> and was shown to arise from a [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]] for the long-range electron-electron correlations.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=David Bohm, David Pines|title=Coulomb Interactions in a Degenerate Electron Gas|journal=Phys. Rev.|date=1 November 1953|volume=92|issue=3|pages=609–625|series=A Collective Description of Electron Interactions: III.|doi=10.1103/physrev.92.609|bibcode = 1953PhRv...92..609B }} Cited after: {{cite journal|title=Alternative derivation of the Bohm-Pines theory of electron-electron interactions|author=N. J. Shevchik |journal=J. Phys. C: Solid State Phys.|date=1974|volume=7|issue=21 |pages=3930–3936|doi=10.1088/0022-3719/7/21/013|bibcode = 1974JPhC....7.3930S }}</ref>
Since plasmons are the quantization of classical plasma oscillations, most of their properties can be derived directly from [[Maxwell's equations]].<ref name="electro"> {{cite book |author=Jackson, J. D. |chapter=10.8 Plasma Oscillations |year=1975 |origyear=1962 |edition=2nd |title=Classical Electrodynamics |location=New York |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |oclc=535998 |isbn=978-0-471-30932-1 }}</ref>
== Explanation ==
Plasmons can be described in the classical picture as an [[oscillation]] of electron density with respect to the fixed positive [[ion]]s in a [[metal]]. To visualize a plasma oscillation, imagine a cube of metal placed in an external [[electric field]] pointing to the right. [[Electron]]s will move to the left side (uncovering positive ions on the right side) until they cancel the field inside the metal. If the electric field is removed, the electrons move to the right, repelled by each other and attracted to the positive ions left bare on the right side. They oscillate back and forth at the [[plasma frequency]] until the [[energy]] is lost in some kind of [[Electrical resistance|resistance]] or [[damping]]. Plasmons are a [[quantization (physics)|quantization]] of this kind of oscillation.
===Role=== Plasmons play a large role in the [[optical]] properties of [[metal]]s and semiconductors. [[Light]] of frequencies below the [[plasma frequency]] is [[Reflection (physics)|reflected]] by a material because the electrons in the material [[Electric field screening|screen]] the [[electric field]] of the light. Light of frequencies above the plasma frequency is transmitted by a material because the electrons in the material cannot respond fast enough to screen it. In most metals, the plasma frequency is in the [[ultraviolet]], making them shiny (reflective) in the visible range. Some metals, such as [[copper]]<ref> {{cite journal |date=1963 |title=Energy Band Structure of Copper |journal=[[Physical Review]] |volume=129 |issue= 1|pages=138–150 |bibcode= 1963PhRv..129..138B |doi=10.1103/PhysRev.129.138 |last1= Burdick |first1= Glenn }}</ref> and [[gold]],<ref>{{cite journal|author=S.Zeng|display-authors=etal|title=A review on functionalized gold nanoparticles for biosensing applications |journal=Plasmonics |volume=6|date=2011|pages= 491–506|doi=10.1007/s11468-011-9228-1|issue=3}}</ref> have electronic interband transitions in the visible range, whereby specific light energies (colors) are absorbed, yielding their distinct color. In [[semiconductor]]s, the [[valence band|valence electron]] plasmon frequency is usually in the deep ultraviolet, while their electronic interband transitions are in the visible range, whereby specific light energies (colors) are absorbed, yielding their distinct color<ref> {{cite book |last=Kittel |first=C. |date=2005 |title=Introduction to Solid State Physics |edition=8th |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |page=403, table 2 |isbn= }}</ref><ref> {{cite book |last=Böer |first=K. W. |title=Survey of Semiconductor Physics |volume=1 |edition=2nd |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |page=525 |isbn= |date=2002 }}</ref> which is why they are reflective. It has been shown that the plasmon frequency may occur in the mid-infrared and near-infrared region when semiconductors are in the form of nanoparticles with heavy doping.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Xin Liu |author2=Mark T. Swihart |title=Heavily-doped colloidal semiconductor and metal oxide nanocrystals: an emerging new class of plasmonic nanomaterials|journal=Chem. Soc. Rev.|date=2014|volume=43|issue=11 |pages=3908–3920|doi=10.1039/c3cs60417a|pmid=24566528 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Xiaodong Pi, Christophe Delerue|title=Tight-binding calculations of the optical response of optimally P-doped Si nanocrystals: a model for localized surface plasmon resonance|journal=Physical Review Letters|date=2013|volume=111|issue=17|pages=177402|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.111.177402|bibcode=2013PhRvL.111q7402P|pmid=24206519}}</ref>
The plasmon energy can often be estimated in the [[free electron model]] as
:[[radiant energy|<math>E_{p} = </math>]][[reduced Planck constant|<math> \hbar </math>]][[Plasma frequency|<math>\sqrt{\frac{n e^{2}}{m\epsilon_0}} = </math>]][[reduced Planck constant|<math>\hbar</math>]][[plasmon frequency|<math>\omega_{p},</math>]]
where <math>n</math> is the [[conduction electron]] density, <math>e</math> is the [[elementary charge]], <math>m</math> is the [[electron mass]], <math>\epsilon_0</math> the [[permittivity of free space]], <math>\hbar</math> the [[reduced Planck constant]] and <math>\omega_{p}</math> the [[plasmon frequency]].
== Surface plasmons == {{Main article|Surface plasmon}} [[Surface plasmon]]s are those plasmons that are confined to surfaces and that interact strongly with light resulting in a [[polariton]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Size dependence of Au NP-enhanced surface plasmon resonance based on differential phase measurement |journal=Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical |date=2013|doi=10.1016/j.snb.2012.09.073|volume=176|pages=1128–1133|display-authors=4|last1=Zeng|first1=Shuwen|last2=Yu|first2=Xia|last3=Law|first3=Wing-Cheung|last4=Zhang|first4=Yating|last5=Hu|first5=Rui|last6=Dinh|first6=Xuan-Quyen|last7=Ho|first7=Ho-Pui|last8=Yong|first8=Ken-Tye |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/268225952 }}</ref> They occur at the interface of a material exhibiting positive real part of their relative permittivity, i.e. [[dielectric constant]], (e.g. vacuum, air, glass and other dielectrics) and a material whose real part of permittivity is negative at the given frequency of light, typically a metal or heavily doped semiconductors. In addition to opposite sign of the real part of the permittivity, the magnitude of the real part of the permittivity in the negative permittivity region should typically be larger than the magnitude of the permittivity in the positive permittivity region, otherwise the light is not bound to the surface (i.e. the surface plasmons do not exist) as shown in the famous book by Raether.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Surface Plasmons on Smooth and Rough Surfaces and on Gratings|last = Raether|first = Heinz|publisher = Springer|year = 1988|isbn = 978-3540173632|location = |pages = 119}}</ref> At visible wavelengths of light, e.g. 632.8 nm wavelength provided by a He-Ne laser, interfaces supporting surface plasmons are often formed by metals like silver or gold (negative real part permittivity) in contact with dielectrics such as air or silicon dioxide. The particular choice of materials can have a drastic effect on the degree of light confinement and propagation distance due to losses. Surface plasmons can also exist on interfaces other than flat surfaces, such as particles, or rectangular strips, v-grooves, cylinders, and other structures. Many structures have been investigated due to the capability of surface plasmons to confine light below the diffraction limit of light.
Surface plasmons can play a role in [[surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy]] and in explaining anomalies in diffraction from metal [[diffraction grating|gratings]] ([[Robert W. Wood|Wood's]] anomaly), among other things. [[Surface plasmon resonance]] is used by [[biochemist]]s to study the mechanisms and kinetics of ligands binding to receptors (i.e. a substrate binding to an [[enzyme]]). [[Multi-parametric surface plasmon resonance]] can be used not only to measure molecular interactions, but also nanolayer properties or structural changes in the adsorbed molecules, polymer layers or graphene, for instance.
Surface plasmons may also be observed in the X-ray emission spectra of metals. A dispersion relation for surface plasmons in the X-ray emission spectra of metals has been derived (Harsh and Agarwal).<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1016/0378-4363(88)90078-2 | volume=150 | issue=3 | title=Surface plasmon dispersion relation in the X-ray emission spectra of a semi-infinite rectangular metal bounded by a plane | journal=Physica B+C | pages=378–384|bibcode = 1988PhyBC.150..378H | last1=Harsh | first1=O. K | last2=Agarwal | first2=B. K | year=1988 }}</ref>
[[File:GothicRayonnantRose003.jpg|thumb|[[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] [[stained glass]] [[rose window]] of [[Notre-Dame de Paris]]. The colors were achieved by [[colloid]]s of gold nano-particles.]] More recently surface plasmons have been used to control colors of materials.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4443854.stm | work=[[BBC News]] | title=LEDs work like butterflies' wings | date=November 18, 2005 | accessdate=May 22, 2010}}</ref> This is possible since controlling the particle's shape and size determines the types of surface plasmons that can couple to it and propagate across it. This in turn controls the interaction of light with the surface. These effects are illustrated by the historic [[stained glass]] which adorn medieval cathedrals. In this case, the color is given by metal nanoparticles of a fixed size which interact with the optical field to give the glass its vibrant color. In modern science, these effects have been engineered for both visible light and [[microwave radiation]]. Much research goes on first in the microwave range because at this wavelength material surfaces can be produced mechanically as the patterns tend to be of the order a few centimeters. To produce optical range surface plasmon effects involves producing surfaces which have features <400 [[nanometer|nm]]. This is much more difficult and has only recently become possible to do in any reliable or available way.
Recently, graphene has also been shown to accommodate surface plasmons, observed via near field infrared optical microscopy techniques<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Jianing Chen, Michela Badioli, Pablo Alonso-González, Sukosin Thongrattanasiri, Florian Huth, Johann Osmond, Marko Spasenović, Alba Centeno, Amaia Pesquera, Philippe Godignon, Amaia Zurutuza Elorza, Nicolas Camara, F. Javier García de Abajo, Rainer Hillenbrand, Frank H. L. Koppens |title=Optical nano-imaging of gate-tunable graphene plasmons |journal=Nature |volume=487 |issue=7405 |pages=77–81 |doi=10.1038/nature11254 |date=5 July 2012 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v487/n7405/abs/nature11254.html |arxiv = 1202.4996 |bibcode = 2012Natur.487...77C |pmid=22722861}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Gate-tuning of graphene plasmons revealed by infrared nano-imaging |authors=Z. Fei, A. S. Rodin, G. O. Andreev, W. Bao, A. S. McLeod, M. Wagner, L. M. Zhang, Z. Zhao, M. Thiemens, G. Dominguez, M. M. Fogler, A. H. Castro Neto, C. N. Lau, F. Keilmann, D. N. Basov |journal=Nature |volume=487 |issue=7405 |pages=82–85 |date=5 July 2012 |doi=10.1038/nature11253 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v487/n7405/full/nature11253.html |bibcode=2012Natur.487...82F|arxiv = 1202.4993 |pmid=22722866}}</ref> and infrared spectroscopy.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Damping pathways of mid-infrared plasmons in graphene nanostructures |authors=Hugen Yan, Tony Low, Wenjuan Zhu, Yanqing Wu, Marcus Freitag, Xuesong Li, Francisco Guinea, Phaedon Avouris, Fengnian Xia |journal=Nature Photonics |volume=7 |issue=5 |pages=394–399 |date=2013 |doi=10.1038/nphoton.2013.57 |url=http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/v7/n5/abs/nphoton.2013.57.html |bibcode = 2013NaPho...7..394Y |arxiv=1209.1984 }}</ref> Potential applications of graphene plasmonics mainly addressed the terahertz to midinfrared frequencies, such as optical modulators, photodetectors, biosensors.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Graphene Plasmonics for Terahertz to Mid-Infrared Applications |authors=Tony Low, Phaedon Avouris |journal=ACS Nano |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=1086–1101 |date=2014 |doi=10.1021/nn406627u |pmid=24484181|arxiv=1403.2799 }}</ref>
== Possible applications == The position and intensity of plasmon absorption and emission peaks are affected by molecular [[adsorption]], which can be used in [[molecular sensor]]s. For example, a fully operational device detecting [[casein]] in milk has been prototyped, based on detecting a change in [[absorption (electromagnetic radiation)|absorption]] of a gold layer.<ref> {{cite journal |last=Heip |first=H. M. |display-authors=etal |date=2007 |title=A localized surface plasmon resonance based immunosensor for the detection of casein in milk |journal=Science and Technology of Advanced Materials |volume=8 |issue= 4|pages=331–338 |bibcode= 2007STAdM...8..331M |doi=10.1016/j.stam.2006.12.010 }}</ref> Localized surface plasmons of metal nanoparticles can be used for sensing different types of molecules, proteins, etc.
Plasmons are being considered as a means of transmitting information on [[Microprocessor|computer chips]], since plasmons can support much higher frequencies (into the 100 [[Terahertz (unit)|THz]] range, whereas conventional wires become very lossy in the tens of [[GHz]]). However, for plasmon-based electronics to be practical, a plasmon-based amplifier analogous to the [[transistor]], called a [[plasmonstor]], needs to be created.<ref> {{cite journal |date=2007 |title=The Promise of Plasmonics |journal=SPIE Professional |volume= |issue= |pages= |bibcode= |doi=10.1117/2.4200707.07 |last1= Lewotsky |first1= Kristin }}</ref>
Plasmons have also been [[Plasmonic nanolithography|proposed]] as a means of high-resolution [[lithography]] and microscopy due to their extremely small wavelengths; both of these applications have seen successful demonstrations in the lab environment.
Finally, surface plasmons have the unique capacity to confine light to very small dimensions, which could enable many new applications.
Surface plasmons are very sensitive to the properties of the materials on which they propagate. This has led to their use to measure the thickness of monolayers on [[colloid]] films, such as screening and quantifying [[protein]] binding events. Companies such as [[Biacore]] have commercialized instruments that operate on these principles. Optical surface plasmons are being investigated with a view to improve makeup by [[L'Oréal]] and others.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.loreal.com/_en/_ww/loreal-art-science/2004winners.aspx?#part2 |title=The L'Oréal Art & Science of Color Prize – 7th Prize Winners }}</ref>
In 2009, a Korean research team found a way to greatly improve [[organic light-emitting diode]] efficiency with the use of plasmons.<ref> {{cite web |date = 9 July 2009 |url = http://www.kaist.edu/english/01_about/06_news_01.php?req_P=bv&req_BIDX=10&req_BNM=ed_news&pt=17&req_VI=2181 |title = Prof. Choi Unveils Method to Improve Emission Efficiency of OLED |publisher = [[KAIST]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110718022905/http://www.kaist.edu/english/01_about/06_news_01.php?req_P=bv&req_BIDX=10&req_BNM=ed_news&pt=17&req_VI=2181 |archivedate = 18 July 2011 |df = }}</ref>
A group of European researchers led by [[IMEC]] has begun work to improve [[solar cell]] efficiencies and costs through incorporation of metallic nanostructures (using plasmonic effects) that can enhance absorption of light into different types of solar cells: crystalline silicon (c-Si), high-performance III-V, organic, and dye-sensitized. <ref> {{cite web |date = 30 March 2010 |title = EU partners eye metallic nanostructures for solar cells |url = http://www.electroiq.com/index/display/photovoltaics-article-display/1202724884/articles/Photovoltaics-World/industry-news/2010/march/eu-partners_eye_metallic.html |publisher = [[ElectroIQ]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110308090541/http://www.electroiq.com/index/display/photovoltaics-article-display/1202724884/articles/Photovoltaics-World/industry-news/2010/march/eu-partners_eye_metallic.html |archivedate = 8 March 2011 |df = }}</ref> However, for plasmonic [[photovoltaic]] devices to function optimally, ultra-thin [[transparent conducting oxide]]s are necessary.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Gwamuri |title=Limitations of ultra-thin transparent conducting oxides for integration into plasmonic-enhanced thin-film solar photovoltaic devices|journal=Materials for Renewable and Sustainable Energy|date=2015|volume=4|issue=12|doi=10.1007/s40243-015-0055-8|url=https://www.academia.edu/14196425|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Full color [[holograms]] using ''plasmonics''<ref name=Kawata2012>{{cite web|last=Kawata|first=Satoshi|title=New technique lights up the creation of holograms|url=http://phys.org/news/2012-03-technique-creation-holograms.html|publisher=Phys.org|accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref> have been demonstrated.
